DOC.HEAD: Complaints Against Noisy Farmer Dropped
DOC.TEXT: A judge dropped charges Monday against a farmer after the suburban neighbors who filed complaints against him, saying he ran a noisy tractor at night, failed to show up in court. However, Cook County Judge John McBride ruled the two counts of disturbing the peace against Ray Dettmering could be reinstated if the neighbors show they had a valid reason for missing the hearing, said David Brauer, village prosecutor in Matteson. ``It's like 90 percent dead,'' Brauer said of the case. ``Both citizens were advised to be here, and they chose not to show.'' Dettmering, 28, was arrested late the night of April 26 after neighbors complained about noise from a plow operating on 60 acres of leased farmland in Matteson south of Chicago. If convicted of both counts, he could have a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Farming supporters quickly seized the case as an example of the continuing conflict between suburban dwellers moving out of the cities and farmers working land right next to the new subdivisions. Neither citizen who signed the complaint returned phone calls to their homes Monday. But both said earlier they didn't know a farmer was involved and neither planned to show up in court Monday. ``I would not have signed the complaint if I'd known he was a farmer,'' Doris Norton said. ``I thought he was a construction foreman for a builder.'' Even though things have worked out in his favor, Dettmering said the issue still isn't resolved because the court gave no direct ruling on whether he could plow at night. He indicated that he'll take his chances. ``I guess it's OK to get back out there,'' he said from the shop in nearby Peotone where he works as a mechanic during the day. But farming officials said the conflict will continue between suburban residents seeking the quiet, pastoral life and working farmers who know it isn't always like that on the north forty. ``People who move out into the country are less tolerant of agricultural practices,'' said Bryan Petrucci, Midwest director for the American Farmland Trust, a nonprofit agency seeking to preserve the nation's agricultural acreage. ``Without more right-to-farm legislation, we will only have more trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty to Killing Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents grafs 10-11, `On Sept. ...'
DOC.TEXT: A 28-year-old man facing trial for the murders of three young boys and the attempted murder of a fourth changed his plea to guilty Monday without explanation. Westley Allan Dodd, of Vancouver has been held without bail since his arrest Nov. 13, when he pleaded innocent to the charges. Jury selection will begin as scheduled on June 25, but only in a consolidated penalty phase for all the cases. Dodd faces the death penalty or mandatory life in prison without parole. Dodd did not indicate why he changed his plea. Clark County Prosecuting Attorney Arthur D. Curtis said Dodd went against the advice of his attorneys. ``We don't feel it was a plea bargain in any respect,'' said Curtis. ``He plead guilty to what he was charged with.'' Dodd softly and somberly described to Clark County Superior Court Judge Robert Harris the three boys' deaths in graphic detail. Dodd was charged with three counts of first-degree aggravated murder in the deaths of 4-year-old Lee Joseph Iseli of Portland, Ore., and Vancouver brothers Cole Neer, 11, and William Neer, 10. The Neer brothers' bodies were found Sept. 4 in a Vancouver park where they had ridden their bicycles. Both had been stabbed. The Iseli boy's body was discovered near Vancouver Lake Nov. 1, three days after he disappeared from a Portland schoolyard. ``On Sept. 4, 1989, I went to David Douglas Park with the premeditated intent to cause the death of another human being,'' Dodd told Harris. ``I raped Cole Neer and then I killed him. Yes, I also murdered William Neer ... to conceal my identity.'' On Oct. 29, Dodd said, ``I did kidnap Lee Iseli from Portland Ore., took him to my apartment in Vancouver and raped him. ... And on the morning of Oct. 30, I murdered Lee Iseli.'' Dodd was arrested after he carried 6-year-old James Kirk II from a Camas, Wash., movie theater. Although the boy was let go outside the theater, his mother's boyfriend tracked Dodd down and brought him back. ``I did attempt to abduct and murder James Kirk,'' Dodd told Harris. Dodd was charged with first-degree kidnapping and first-degree attempted murder in that case. The kidnapping charge was dropped Monday. Robert Iseli, whose son was one of those killed, said he hoped Dodd would get the death penalty. ``You shoot a rabid dog ... and anyone else who has no value to society,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Teachers Want Greater Voice in School Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf: ``We also,'' to CORRECT location of school from Albuquerque to Los Alamos
DOC.TEXT: Classroom teachers want input on designing curriculums, selecting principals, choosing textbooks and spending school funds, according to a Gallup Poll released Monday. ``Teachers overwhelmingly want more say in everything,'' said Donna Rhodes, director of the National Foundation for the Improvement of Education, one of several groups that sponsored the study. The poll found that teachers believe they can make a difference in changing overall education policy and reforming the educational system on virtually all levels, if given the opportunity. It was released as a gathering of education and business leaders recognized 115 elementary and secondary school teachers from 23 areas. Sixty-three percent of the respondents said they believed they could influence change in their own school ``a great deal.'' Another 35 percent said a ``fair amount,'' while 2 percent said ``not very much.'' Ninety-six percent said the role of teachers should be expanded in the area of educational decision-making. More than nine out of 10 favored school-based decision-making, which teachers say will give them a greater voice in what happens in their classrooms. The poll found that 86 percent wanted public school teachers to have more say in the allocation of funds, 78 percent wanted more influence over curriculum, 56 percent believed they should participate in the hiring of other teachers and 69 percent wanted input into the selection of the building principal. In addition, 71 percent wanted to help choose books and instructional materials, 78 percent wanted a voice in setting teacher and administrative salaries, and 54 percent wanted a say-so in tenure decisions. ``We also want policy makers to come into the classroom,'' said Roberta E. Cocking of the Los Alamos Middle School in Los Alamos, N.M., one of the teachers being recognized. She said few policy makers know much about what goes on day-to-day in classrooms. Gallup in May polled 231 semifinalists in this year's ``Thanks To Teachers'' program. The margin of error is plus or minus 6 percent. The program singles out teachers from across the nation for recognition. It is sponsored by the foundation, the National Alliance of Business, Apple Computer Inc. and Group W Television Sales. Rhodes said, ``We believe the poll's findings are significant because they represent the opinions of some of the best teachers in the country _ educators whose communities view them as the best and value what they do,'' said Rhodes. ``Their perception of the condition of education today is reflective of that held by the public at large,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Plane Crashes, Killing Two
DOC.TEXT: A small plane crashed and burned Monday at the end of the runway at Fairbanks International Airport after its engine stalled, killing both people aboard, a spokesman said. The two-seat Taylorcraft had taken off from the airport's gravel strip and climbed about 600 feet when the engine stalled around 4:20 p.m., said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Paul Steucke. The plane was destroyed by the fire, Steucke said. Investigators from the FAA and the National Transportation Safety Board were at the scene, but it was too soon to know the cause of the crash, Steucke said. The victims' names were not released. The plane was privately owned, Steucke said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Wounded as Hostage Incident Ends in British Columbia
DOC.TEXT: A man held four sheriffs and an interpreter hostage for more than six hours at a courthouse Monday before an exchange of gunfire that left the gunman and three police officers wounded, police said. None of the hostages were hurt and two of the wounded officers suffered only superficial injuries in the incident in this Vancouver suburb, said police Cpl. Casey deHaas. All four wounded were taken to a hospital. There was no immediate word on the seriousness of the wounds suffered by the gunman or the third officer. Police identified the hostage-taker as a 38-year-old man who had gone to court to appeal a three-month sentence for violating crab fishing regulations and a three-month sentence for obstructing justice. The man had been free on bail but was taken into custody as a condition of bail immediately before his court appearance Monday, deHaas said. The man took the four provincial sheriffs and an interpreter hostage around 10 a.m. PDT in the courthouse lockup. Police cordoned off the area in back of the courthouse, and a police negotatior talked to the man over the phone. Members of New Westminster's Emergency Response Team moved into place. At 4:20 p.m. PDT, more than a dozen shots were heard. Police said the shots were confined to the lockup. Seconds after the shots, witnesses saw an Emergency Response Team member emerge, clutching his side. The officer collapsed. Police believe the gunman brought a large-caliber handgun to the courthouse. DeHaas said there were no metal detectors at the courthouse Monday, although portable detectors are used for high-security cases.

DOC.HEAD: List of Worst U.S. Oil Spills
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of 10 of the worst oil spills in U.S. history according to Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin, which has kept records since 1976.

1. March 24, 1989, Exxon Valdez, Prince William Sound, Alaska, 10.92 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 2. Nov. 1, 1979, Burmah Agate tanker, Galveston Bay, Texas, up to 10.7 million gallons of oil burned or spilled when two ships collided. 3. Dec. 15, 1976, Argo Merchant tanker, Massachusetts' southeastern coast, 7.6 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 4. Nov. 6, 1985, exploratory well, Ranger, Texas, 6.3 million gallons of oil spilled after a blowout. 5. Jan. 2, 1988, Ashland Oil Co., above-ground storage tank, Jefferson Borough, Pa., 3.8 million gallons of oil spilled when a tank ruptured. 6. July 30, 1984, Alvenus tanker, Cameron, La., 2.8 million gallons of oil spilled after a ship ran aground. 7. Oct. 31, 1984, Puerto Rican tanker, San Francisco, 2 million gallons of oil spilled when a ship caught fire following an explosion. 8. Aug. 18, 1984, Triangle Oil Corp., above-ground storage tank, Jacksonville, Fla., 2.5 million gallons of oil burned after lightning sparked a fire. 9. Nov. 22, 1980, Georgia tanker, Pilottown, La., 1.3 million gallons of oil spilled after an anchor chain caused a ship to leak. 10. March 31, 1982, Arkas tanker, Montz, La., 1.47 million gallons of oil burned and spilled after a ship collision and fire.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Dedicates Professional Life to AIDS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In 1984, Ellen Altmann's boss at LaGuardia Hospital told her she was spending too much time assisting a man who had AIDS. The physicians were angry with her and worried she was going to catch the disease by being in the same room with him so often. So she did the only thing she felt she could do. ``When I handed in my resignation,'' Ellen said, ``I told them, `I've decided to work exclusively with patients with AIDS.''' Her supervisor was astounded. ``What, are you crazy? Aren't you afraid? You want to have a family someday. You're going to catch something!'' ``I'm not afraid,'' Ellen said. ``I'm just not ignorant.'' Since the time before AIDS had a name, Ellen and Ed Altmann have built their professional _ and sometimes, personal _ lives around caring for people with the fatal, incurable disease. They are both nurses, colleagues for seven years, spouses for five, taking on the job it seemed at times no one else wanted. ``AIDS is especially nursing's disease,'' said Ellen, 32, now the head nurse for the newly opened AIDS unit at Lenox Hill Hospital on Manhattan's Upper East Side. ``I could work in a doctor's office, I could work in a lab, I could work in surgery, I could work in maternal-child health, where a lot of things are mostly happy. ``But I think this is really the essence of nursing.'' If AIDS is nursing's disease, as the Altmanns believe, it is because medical technology has made so little headway against it. Nursing care can make a difference, can help keep a person with the full-blown disease out of the hospital. But few drugs have any impact on the inexorable ravages of the virus. ``I think this is a particularly insane profession, very strenuous, where you're always facing insurmountable odds,'' said Ed, 36, who works in the nursing end of AIDS research running drug trials for the Community Research Initiative. ``Working in a field like this, keeping that separation between personal and professional, keeping some control over your life, it really is a skill. A lot of people do burn out ... but to stay in it, you really have to develop those boundaries for yourself.'' There have been many times in their lives when the boundaries between their personal and professional lives have disappeared, lost in their passion for their cause. After Ellen resigned, she and Ed went to St. Clare's, a small, aging Roman Catholic hospital tucked into Manhattan's tough Hell's Kitchen neighborhood. There, in the city's first dedicated AIDS unit, they worked 14-hour days creating what would become a model for other hospitals. The two of them were the entire nursing staff, a pair with distinctly different yet complementary styles. She's intense, matter-of-fact, a doer who exudes confidence and competence; he's more easy-going, a low-key observer who seems quietly self-assured. They also were newlyweds, spending 24 hours a day together, supporting each other, fighting the tough fight and loving it. ``We spent more time together working than we ever have,'' Ellen said. ``We were fighting for a cause together, something we were both committed to.'' ``It was a tremendous task and a thankless job,'' Ed said. ``But by doing it, by putting ourselves in that situation, we got the opportunity to learn how the system really works, how to start a new program and make it fit into a hospital that's very resistant to change.'' At first, the doctors wouldn't come to their floor, the housekeepers wouldn't come, the X-ray technicians wouldn't come. The kitchen served patients' meals on paper trays. The fear was palpable. Gradually, that changed. As the years passed, staffers who had resented mandatory AIDS education classes that Ellen taught began asking for them. What never changed was the relative youth of the patients, many of them vital people at the height of their careers, and the inevitability of their deterioration. ``We both ended up getting involved with special patients who, for one reason or another, became very close to us,'' Ellen said. ``We were able to support each other through their deaths.'' As patients have become their friends over the years, so some of their friends have become patients. For months, the Altmanns took turns nursing a friend who required daily care. They were the only ones he would allow administer his twice-daily intravenous medication. Either Ed or Ellen would visit him in the morning before work, and the other would come in the evening. They kept their home stocked with IV supplies in case he was visiting their Queens neighborhood. ``We never made any plans that didn't include seeing him or communicating with him in some way,'' Ellen said. ``We restricted our lives based on how he was feeling, because we always wanted to be available. ``It was really stressful, and there were times we were angry. We shouldn't have gotten so involved _ but how could we not?'' she said, adding that their care helped the friend avoid two or three hospitalizations. He died in January. ``I don't regret any of it,'' Ellen said. ``Even though at times it seemed overwhelming for him to be so dependent on us, and us to have all our social plans revolved around his care, I would not have done it any differently.'' Still, the days are gone when they would unhesitatingly dedicate every spare minute to AIDS care with little thought to their personal lives. Now, Ed spends two days a week at home with their 20-month-old son, Joshua, and Ellen makes it a point to work regular hours and spend evenings and weekends with her family. But the nature of their work _ the intensity of the demands, the inevitability of death _ means they always will need to look to each other for special support. ``When you're talking to a friend who is not a nurse, and they ask, `What do you do?' I can't possibly answer that,'' Ellen said. ``I can talk to you for weeks and weeks and weeks, and you still wouldn't understand all the things I do as a nurse. And Ed understands.'' ``Sometimes,'' Ed said, ``just a couple of words, and I know exactly what she's going through.''

DOC.HEAD: Couple Struggles With Specter of AIDS Day by Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Young love blossomed two years ago at a hospital detox center. Sara and Rafael were both 20, both shooting heroin and cocaine, both looking for a way out. They found each other. ``When we started, he was determined to stop drugs,'' said Sara, who didn't want her real name used. ``I would go get high, and I would curse him out. He would say, `Come on. We can change together.' '' The detox program didn't change them. But 18 months ago, they joined the Addiction Research & Treatment Corp.'s Heterosexual and HIV transmission study. The five-year study involves counseling and periodic follow-ups. Participants are tested for exposure to the AIDS virus. Sara tested positive. Rafael did not. And that changed everything. ``I felt cheated,'' she said, thinking of the moment when she read the results. ``Here I am getting my life together, and this ... is happening to me?'' ``She went crazy,'' said Rafael, who also did not want his name used. ``She said she was going to get high again that day. She said she was going to do drugs. I was watching her, because I was nervous she was going to do something crazy, something stupid.'' She cried, and he held her. ``I love you,'' he told her. ``It doesn't matter.'' But Sara's anger and confusion were overwhelming. For a month, she washed her dishes in bleach for fear her nieces or nephews would somehow catch the virus from her. She wouldn't let anyone touch her. She couldn't believe Rafael wanted to stay with her. ``I tell him that if I had found out he had it, I would have left him,'' Sara said. ``And I tell her, `Not everybody's the same. You got your feelings, I've got mine,' '' Rafael replied. ``I know she got hurt, knowing that she got it. I'm going to treat her bad, too? I didn't treat her bad, and she wanted to go kill herself anyway. Imagine if I had said, `I'm leaving you now.' Maybe she would have done it.'' Sara knows when she was exposed. She shared a needle with her older sister, who had said she carried the AIDS virus. Sara didn't believe her. Now it is Rafael who has a hard time believing. ``He doesn't face it. He doesn't face it at all. To him, this is like a flu that's going to get better,'' Sara said. ``He says, `I know you're not going to die.' He doesn't face it at all. And we talk about this every day, that he has to accept it, that I'm going to get sick. And that he has to go on with his life. ``He says, `It's not true. Don't worry about it. You're going to keep living.' I say, `Please listen to me. This is happening to us.' He doesn't want to hear it.'' About 20 percent of the 12,236 women with AIDS in the United States are Hispanic, like Sara, even though Hispanics make up just 7 percent of the population. More than half of those women contracted AIDS through needle-sharing, like Sara and her sister. ``If we had both had it, it would have been OK. But he didn't have it, and I felt like I was depriving him of his life. I told him that day, `Do your life. You can find somebody else,''' said Sara, who grew up in the Bronx and now lives with Rafael in her mother's house. This brown-eyed man with the soft voice and gentle ways is the best thing in her life. The worst thing is the possibility that she might infect him. ``I don't want to get him sick. That's my biggest fear. It would be worse for me to know I got him sick than to know I'm sick myself.'' The risk of contracting AIDS is at least 15 times greater for black and Hispanic heterosexuals than for white heterosexuals. Heterosexual contact between intravenous drug users and their partners is spreading the virus faster than any other transmission mode, with the number of those cases up 27 percent from 1988 to 1989. Sara and Rafael know the risks. Rafael told their counselor, Regina Phillips, that he was afraid he would hurt Sara's feelings if he insisted on using condoms. Now it is Sara who insists, often without success. ``He doesn't want to protect himself. I bought all kinds of them, $7 for one of them. He won't use them,'' she said. ``It wouldn't hurt me, if he uses them. It would hurt me more if he got sick. That would kill me.'' Sara has an associate degree in business administration, but she can't work. She looks healthy behind her bright lipstick and pink-framed glasses. But she has lost almost 20 pounds, and spends many days trying to sleep off her weakness and fatigue. ``I don't have no future,'' she said, but later talked about the simple wedding they plan for August and her desire to sharpen her typing skills, get a job and become involved in religion. ``If I get it in my head that there's hope, that maybe I'll do better, and it doesn't come ...,'' her voice trails off. ``I know I'm going to get sick. It's going to happen eventually. So I take one day at a time, one day at a time. Some days I feel strong. Some days I don't. ``I live that day. And I thank God that night that I lived that day.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Create Multiple Parties, Not Multiparty System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-New Political Views
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir Zhironovsky, chairman of the Liberal Democrats, conducts interviews on a park bench, not in an office. His party couldn't afford an office even if one were available. ``We don't have any money, we don't have any press, we don't have any advertising,'' he said on the bench in a quiet, shady corner of Sokolniki Park in northeast Moscow. Nikolai Travkin, a plain-spoken former Communist Party member who is forming a populist movement, incites disgruntled citizens to throw out his former comrades. The Russian Social Democrats are looking for coalition partners, and Communists need not apply. Dozens of parties have formed since the Communists and the national legislature agreed in February to end the party's monopoly on power. The political spectrum ranges from monarchist to anarchist, but the Communist Party remains dominant. Communist reformer Vyacheslav N. Shostakovsky said the newcomers present a sideshow of ``proto-parties'' while a struggle for control goes on in the 19-million member organization that has ruled the Soviet Union since 1917. Travkin agrees what counts is not the number of parties, but their ability to mount a nationwide challenge to the Communists. ``You can create as many parties as you want, but the Communist Party will strangle them like chickens,'' he told supporters at a rally. In pressing for an end to the constitutional monopoly of power, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Communists would ``struggle for the status of the ruling party'' rather than having it guaranteed. Whatever the theory, the party still controls newspapers, radio and television. It has lost none of the vast staff and organizational experience built up over 70 years, and party cells in factories, ministries, the military and KGB secret police have not been eliminated. Opponents of the Communists have none of those advantages, but also lack the party's big disadvantage: a legacy of repression and mismanagement that is an easy target to attack. Oleg Rumyantsev said his Social Democrats ``are morally and politically opposed to the ideology and practical ways of revolutionary communism epitomized by the Bolsheviks.'' The party will consider a coalition with anyone except the Communists, he told the Interfax news service. Zhironovsky of the Liberal Democrats is a lawyer and proponent of free markets who has spent years on the edge of the dissident movement. He believes the Soviet Communists are going the way of Eastern Europe's failed regimes. ``The question is how they are going to leave, and when,'' he said. Many prominent people criticize the Communist Party, but forcing it out will not be easy. No big names have joined the small opposition groups. Telephones and apartments are so scarce there is no place for Zhironovsky to put the Liberal Democrat headquarters, so he splits it between his apartment and his office at a publishing house. He hopes that, in the interests of political stability, the Communists will decide to hand over some of their plentiful office space. Without a regular headquarters, he said, it is impossible for his 9,000-member group to maintain regular contacts even with legislators. Lawmakers ``have a mass of other problems, and they're going to spend two or three days looking for me?'' he asked. The Communist reformer, Shostakovsky, said small parties do not yet pose a serious challenge and the main contest is between reformers and conservatives within the Communist Party. ``There are monarchists in the party, as strange as it seems, and there are anarchists,'' said Shostakovsky, rector of Moscow's Higher Party School. He is a leader of Democratic Platform, reformers who want the party leadership to abandon the idea of leading and organizing the entire society. Other members include Boris N. Yeltsin, just elected president of the Russian Federation; historian Yuri Afanasiev and Gavriil Popov, mayor of Moscow. Some kind of party split is almost certain. A struggle now is under way for control of the party center, and with it the majority of members. Shostakovsky fears an attempt to seize control by party hard-liners, who accused Gorbachev's economic advisers in documents published May 13 of intending to dismantle Soviet socialism. They condemned ``private enterprise, legalization of accumulating capital, thirst for profit and individualism.'' A national party Central Committee document criticized Democratic Platform this spring for threatening to split the party if it cannot force reform. The differences probably will come to a head at the 28th party congress beginning July 2, and it is not certain what direction Gorbachev will take. Shostakovsky said he did not expect Gorbachev to propose great changes. If none occurred, he said, Democratic Platform would leave and take 500,000 to 600,000 supporters along. It would be the largest opposition group by far, but still a dwarf beside the mother party. Despite the prominence of many of its members, Democratic Platform would face many of the difficulties confronted by other opposition groups. Most of its supporters are intellectuals and highly skilled workers, and Shostakovsky acknowledged it had virtually no support in the countryside. Democratic Platform probably would cooperate with Gorbachev as much as possible, playing the role of a loyal opposition rather than trying to take power away from him. Travkin, whose populist message has found an audience with radical workers, has been a member of Democratic Platform and still has a ``partnership'' relationship with it, Shostakovsky said. He added, however, that Travkin was pressing too hard. ``There is a taste of confrontation about it, extremely tough confrontation,'' he said. As for Travkin, he said his populist Democratic Party of Russia wants to replace local Communist leaders, not engage in ``endless round tables'' to negotiate issues. Shostakovsky said opponents may be surprised by the Communists' staying power. They have watched Soviet-inspired parties in Eastern Europe quickly reduced to demoralized minority parties, he said, but communism was imposed there and was homegrown in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Unusual Lineup in Arkansas Tops Primary Balloting
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist faces a black businessman in an Arkansas runoff today for the GOP nomination for lieutenant governor. In South Carolina, two state senators compete for a chance to run against Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell. In other voting: _Atlantic City, N.J., Mayor James L. Usry, under indictment on corruption charges, tries to hold onto his job in a non-partisan runoff with City Councilman Jim Whelan. _North Dakota voters decide whether to raise the sales tax from 5 percent to 6 percent for a year to bail out education. _Maine has primaries in both parties to pick nominees for the congressional seat held by Democrat Joseph E. Brennan. He is giving up the seat to try to regain his job as governor. The Arkansas runoff was required when Ralph Forbes, 50-year-old evangelist for the Sword of the Lord Good News Ministries, polled 46 percent of the vote in the May 29 primary, short of the majority needed to win the nomination. The second-place finisher, with 36 percent, was Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, who previously lost bids for seats in the General Assembly and the Little Rock Board of Directors. ``In listening to folks who I know are Republicans and talking to them, they are not very enamored with either candidate,'' said Bill Paschall, a Little Rock political consultant. ``They wished a stronger candidate had stepped forward. Now it's a matter of the best of the weak.'' Forbes believes that whites and blacks would be better off under separate governments. In an interview Sunday with the Arkansas Democrat, he proclaimed that ``white Christian Americans are the true lost tribe of Israel'' and said that the sight of an interracial couple ``turns my stomach.'' Virtually every prominent Republican in the state has endorsed Harris, 36, an executive with a company that manufactures hair care products for blacks. Sheffield Nelson, the GOP gubernatorial nominee, ran TV advertisements this week denouncing Forbes. The winner of the runoff will face Jim Guy Tucker, a former congressman who won a seven-way Democratic primary. The lieutenant governor presides over the state Senate and takes over the governor's duties when the governor is out of state. That makes it a low-profile job ordinarily, but Gov. Bill Clinton travels a great deal and may be traveling more if he runs for president, as many expect. In South Carolina, state Sens. Theo Mitchell and Ernest Passailaigue waged populist campaigns for the chance to face Campbell, who is only the second Republican governor in the state this century and is highly popular. Passailaigue, a 42-year-old accountant from Charleston, won his first bid for office in 1988. He has been a frequent challenger of Senate leadership despite his freshman status, pushing unsuccessfully for tax reform. Mitchell, a 51-year-old Greenville lawyer and state lawmaker since 1974, has represented a racially mixed district for the past six years. He has been a proponent of public transportation and assistance to the poor. If victorious in November, Mitchell would become the state's first black governor. In Maine, the Democratic front-runner in a five-way congressional race is Attorney General James E. Tierney. Two Republicans are in the race: David F. Emery, who held the seat for eight years until 1982, and state Rep. John McCormick. McCormick opposes abortion rights. Emery has changed his position and is now pro-choice. Three GOP senators faced no primary opposition today in their bids for re-election. Sen. John W. Warner of Virginia won't even face a major party opponent in November. The state Democratic Central Committee, meeting Saturday, decided not to oppose him. Sen. William S. Cohen of Maine will face Democratic state Rep. Neil Rolde in November, and Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina will be challenged in November by Democrat Robert Cunningham.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Control Valuable Commodity _ Water
DOC.TEXT: In the arid West, where water is more valuable than gold, the Wind River Indian Reservation considers itself awash in wealth. The Indians last year won rights to much of the water in west-central Wyoming. Now their destiny is no longer entirely in the hands of the white man, who relegated them to the 2.5 million-acre reservation in the mid-1800s. ``Look how many years we've taken the back seat to everything,'' says Burton Hutchinson, Northern Arapaho tribal chairman. ``We're the ones in the driver's seat now. It feels good. Real good. Real nice.'' The U.S. Supreme Court last year ruled that an 1868 treaty gave the Northern Arapahos and Shoshones priority rights to 500,000 acre-feet of water from the Wind River _ roughly twice what the 6,000 Indians previously controlled. An acre-foot is enough to cover an acre to a depth of one foot. Among other things, the Indians hope to attract tourists and anglers to the river by maintaining the flow rather than diverting water to irrigation in dry times. ``I want to see the day when every tribal member who wants to work can,'' said Wes Martel, co-chairman of the Shoshone Business Council. ``I want to see the day when everyone on the reservation who wants an education can get one, when the elders can get the medical care they need and when the reservation stands out as an example of what can be done when people can plan for the future,'' he added. ``And this water is the key to all of that.'' However, the Indians' newfound wealth has brought them into conflict with non-Indian farmers on the reservation. In the past Indians and non-Indians shared water in dry times. But after the Supreme Court ruling, the tribes began making sure their water rights were observed before sending water to the non-Indian farmers, some of whose ancestors homesteaded the area with federal assurances they would have water. In early May, when runoff was scarce, the tribes shut off water to about 30 non-Indians in a section that relies on canals for water from the Wind. ``It's pretty frustrating to watch your sprinkler sit there idle while your neighbor sits there and uses 12,000 gallons of water to irrigate land covered mostly with foxtails,'' said Fran Fox, a non-Indian farmer. ``Each day you watch water go down the river that should be in your canal,'' said another farmer, Tim Shell. ``Before this started, we shared water by rotation and we all survived. The rules have changed now. Some are prospering and some will be a lot worse off.'' To alleviate disputes last year, the state paid the tribes $5.3 million to secure water for the non-Indian irrigators. But efforts to reach another agreement for this year broke down in February, with the state saying the price the Indians were asking was too high. Reservation hydrologist Catherine Vandemoer said the Indians are not obligated to give the non-Indians any water at all. And she said that as runoff increases this spring, enough water should be available for everyone. ``They will be fine the rest of the summer,'' she said. ``These people really have nothing to worry about.'' But the non-Indian farmers complain that the lack of water has already cost them barley and hay. ``We are talking about 65 to 70 bushels (of barley per acre) as opposed to 100,'' Fox said. ``My hay will be less than half of a crop.'' Non-Indians on the reservation ``have no representation; we are disenfranchised,'' Fox said. ``We are feeling a little lonely.'' Martel said the Indians are trying to manage the water in a way that will improve the reservation's economy. ``We've got to do something to alleviate the 70 percent unemployment and provide health care for our people who are not getting it,'' said Martel. ``If we didn't have such potential, things here would be a little depressing. We are just trying to protect what little we have left.''

DOC.HEAD: Killer Wasps Can Reduce Pesticide Hazards
DOC.TEXT: Farmers soon may have an environmentally safe alternative to pesticides _ swarms of tiny wasps trained for search-and-destroy missions against two of the nation's most destructive crop pests. Researchers at a U.S. Department of Agriculture laboratory in Tifton are experimenting with odors and colors to enhance the wasp's natural bloodhound ability to locate corn ear and tobacco bud worms. The two caterpillars attack at least 100 plants, including corn, cotton, soybeans and tomatoes. They are members of the Heliothis pest family, blamed for more than $1 billion in crop losses each year. Joe Lewis, an entomologist with the USDA's Agricultural Research Service, and visiting Dutch student Felix Wackers are raising small wasps known as Microplitis croceipes. They are natural enemies of Heliothis insects but do not harm humans. The Heliothis pests often try to evade the enemies by hiding in crevices of plants and leaving decoy sites with their scents. ``The wasps are like detectives,'' Lewis said. ``They're monitoring, eavesdropping. By understanding how they identify clues that signal the caterpillar's presence, we can turn them into an asset.'' The female wasp deposits an egg inside the caterpillar while stinging. The egg hatches into a larva, feeds inside the host and eventually kills the caterpillar. The larva then leaves and spins a cocoon in which it develops into a wasp. As the wasps emerge from the cocoon, the caterpillar odor left on the cocoon is sensed by the wasp and used later to locate hosts for its eggs, Lewis said. To use wasps to kill pests, large numbers will have to be raised in laboratories. But ``if you released them in a cornfield and they didn't have any training for worms, they might fly off to another field,'' said Wackers. So the researchers are using Pavlovian techniques to make the wasps more efficient killers. They have conditioned wasps to recognize the odor of caterpillar feces and pick out cues such as the color and shape of a cotton bloom. Wasps that received caterpillars as rewards were 90 percent effective in choosing the correct odors and colored cards in flight chamber tests. Similar results were achieved when wasps were released in small plots. ``We can program them to seek a certain kind of plant and a certain part of the plant in searching for pests,'' said Lewis. Wasps are already used for pest control in greenhouses in Europe and the United States. It has always been assumed that insect behavior was determined by instinct, but Lewis said his tests have shown the wasps can be trained. In one experiment, he taught them to associate the smell of vanilla with caterpillars. ``Our ability to train them to respond to such novel and otherwise unattractive odors demonstrates the remarkable capacity of these wasps to learn,'' Lewis said. The researchers estimate that by 1995, parasitic wasps could be sent out to patrol full-sized fields.

DOC.HEAD: Crime Bill Poses Test of Gun Lobby's Clout
DOC.TEXT: Texas Sen. Phil Gramm knows the rewards of having the National Rifle Association as an ally. Michael Dukakis, on the other hand, knows what it's like to lead the NRA's list of enemies. The organization uses its cash-rich political action committee to support its political allies and in the past has dug deep into its coffers to attack candidates it views as opponents. The current Senate debate over a major crime bill that includes bans on nine categories of semiautomatic weapons is the latest test of the NRA's clout. The association won a round last Thursday when it got enough votes to stall action on the bill. But it likely will be tested again in the coming weeks, as even Republican lawmakers considered staunch NRA allies seek a compromise so the Congress can pass an election-year crime bill. History says the NRA will remember the votes come fall. And its PAC has the money to affect campaigns, holding more than $631,000 at the end of May, according to Federal Election Commission records. The PAC raised $1.2 million in the 15 months ending in March _ the 24th best showing among more than 4,500 registered committees _ and already had donated $320,000 to congressional candidates in the 1990 cycle. Like many wealthy PACs, it not only gives directly to candidates but also uses media ads and mail appeals to influence targeted campaigns. Gramm, a conservative Republican who is a natural NRA ally, received $9,900 directly from the PAC for his 1984 election campaign. It also spent $327,850 on an independent drive to support his candidacy. Dukakis, the Massachusetts governor and 1988 Democratic presidential nominee, was on the other end of an NRA independent-expenditure campaign. FEC records show the NRA spent more than $1.5 million against Dukakis, much of that on radio ads and direct mail appeals that accused Dukakis of vowing to disarm his state. Dukakis said the ads distorted his views and at one point he threatened to sue the NRA. Still, his campaign was forced to counter with ads of its own _ diverting valuable campaign money and air time. FEC records show most of the 37 senators whose vote helped the NRA's position in the Senate last Thursday have received campaign help from the organization. Over the past six years, the NRA has spent nearly $700,000 on behalf of 33 of the 37 senators, according to FEC records. The six-year period was chosen because 1984 was the last time some senators were up for re-election. More than $240,000 of the spending by the NRA's political committee was in the form of campaign donations to the 33. The NRA's PAC spent an additional $440,000 on advertising and other independent efforts to support of five of the 33, including the nearly $330,000 spent to support Gramm. The Thursday vote came on a motion to limit the length of debate on the crime bill, with the Senate leadership falling three short of the 60 votes it needed. Supporting the leadership in that unsuccessful effort were 21 senators who in the past six years have received financial help from the NRA. The records show that NRA spent more than $240,000 on behalf of the 21; $112,600 in direct contributions and $130,450 on independent efforts to support four of the 21. Ten of the 21 lawmakers sided with the NRA two weeks ago when an amendment that would have removed the gun controls from the legislation failed on a 52-48 vote. But last week the 10 sided with the leadership in trying to limit debate. Among them was Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., who according to FEC records benefited from a $112,000 NRA independent expenditure campaign in 1986. Specter is coauthor of a provision in the bill designed to speed up certain executions, and his vote Thursday was interpreted more as an effort to keep the overall crime bill alive than as a rebuke to the NRA. Also among the 10 lawmakers who supported the NRA stance earlier but sided with the leadership last week was Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, who has received $15,000 from the NRA over the past six years. If the bill clears the Senate with the bans on semiautomatic weapons, the NRA's lobbying effort will shift to the House, where it also has dozens of staunch allies. The NRA's PAC has donated more than $2 million to House candidates in the past six years. But its chances of deleting the bans from the legislation in the House are not considered as strong as in the Senate. Democrats, generally supportive of the bans, hold a bigger majority in the House and the rules of that chamber forbid filibusters.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Pay Raise Yet to Emerge as Issue With Clout
DOC.TEXT: If voters are truly outraged about the big pay raise the House gave itself, they're not registering it at the only place that really counts _ the ballot box. The bulk of the primary election season was completed as of last Tuesday, and the results show that not one incumbent was defeated because of a vote for the raise, which will boost House salaries to about $125,000 in January 1991 from the current $96,600. Only one incumbent lost for any reason, and that was Rep. Donald E. ``Buz'' Lukens, R-Ohio, whose party abandoned him after he was convicted of sexual improprieties with a minor. It's not that challengers didn't try to use the pay issue. In fact, a handful of veteran Democrats had close calls where the pay issue was used against them, most notably Rep. John Murtha of Pennsylvania. The chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the nation's military spending _ and a pay-raise booster _ Murtha received barely more than 50 percent of the vote in defeating a little-known and thinly financed opponent. For a few days last month after Murtha's scare, the Capitol was abuzz. Was the pay issue bigger than they thought? If someone as powerful as Murtha be brought to his knees, was any not vulnerable? But now that talk has settled down. Political analysts found other, local reasons at the root of Murtha's troubles. And some other Democrats who expected primary trouble have came through with bigger-than-expected margins despite their pay-raise votes. ``Any member of Congress who is doing a good job, responsive to his or her district and is well loved by the district will not be defeated by his or her vote on the pay raise,'' said Howard Schloss, spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. ``They all won, and that's the bottom line,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., who spearheaded the drive last year for the pay raise and ethics-reform legislation. ``I really believe the issue is behind us.'' That high level of confidence is due, in part, to something known on Capitol Hill but not widely known elsewhere. Before passing the pay raise last year, the two parties agreed not to use it against each others' candidates. For the intra-party warfare of the primary elections, that pact didn't apply, but it will in November. So, the feeling is that House incumbents have already withstood the toughest shots. Fazio says the heat is now on the Senate, which rejected the big 25 percent increase the House gets next year and decided instead to let its members keep taking fees of up to $2,000 a speech from special-interest groups. Several senators have promised to try again this year to ban such honoraria. Fazio cites California voters' strong 62 percent approval last week of Proposition 112, which would prohibit state lawmakers from accepting money for speeches and set up a commission to set pay increases. The House voted to ban speech honoraria beginning next year, as part of the pay deal. And there are other similarities with California _ for example, the strong opposition to both plans by consumer activist Ralph Nader. Nader and others remain confident the issue will heat up again for the fall election. Several top political analysts have wondered aloud if the pay raise won't feed into a general mood of discontent among the voters. History is a poor guide on this one. Congressional Quarterly researched the issue recently and found that voters did indeed toss members out in droves when they passed big pay increases in 1816 and 1873. But in 1855 and a century later, in 1955, pay increases of 50 percent and 80 percent were passed without resulting in any great electoral turmoil. The feeling in the Capitol, based on the primary results, is that 1990 is looking a lot like 1955.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Steven Komarow is a congressional correspondent for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Activists See Iowa as `Test Tube' for Abortion Strategy
DOC.TEXT: Activists on both sides of the abortion issue see Iowa's gubernatorial and U.S. Senate races as a ``test tube'' in which to develop campaign strategies that can be put to work elsewhere. The dividing lines sharpened last week when Democrats nominated pro-choice House Speaker Don Avenson to run against first-term Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, who opposes abortion. The state's Senate race also matches up candidates on opposing sides of the abortion issue. Anti-abortion Republican Rep. Tom Tauke is hoping to oust Sen. Tom Harkin, who is pro-choice on abortion. ``Iowa is one of the most important states in terms of gubernatorial races and Senate races,'' said Loretta Ucelli of the National Abortion Rights Action League, or NARAL. ``The stakes are very high there.'' Mona Smit of the Iowa Right to Life Committee said the November elections ``now become a high priority as Iowans now have a clear choice.'' Activists on both sides of the abortion issue say they will wage high-profile campaigns in Iowa, which holds the nation's first test of presidential strength. Political tactics often get a trial run in Iowa before being put into play elsewhere. ``Iowa is sort of a test tube for campaign strategy and techniques,'' said Joe Shanahan, a spokesman for the Iowa Democratic Party. ``We have pretty much a fulltime campaign going on.'' Both Democratic candidates, Harkin and Avenson, say they will make their pro-choice positions an important part of the fall campaigns. ``I don't think we can beat Terry Branstad unless we offer voters a contrast,'' Avenson said of the governor's race. ``All eyes are going to be on Iowa this year,'' Harkin said. ``This is the one Senate race where there is a clear-cut difference.'' Last week's primary was the first election in the state since the U.S. Supreme Court last year gave states more freedom to restrict abortion. Pro-choice activists said Avenson's primary election victory over anti-abortion Attorney General Tom Miller demonstrated the political clout of the abortion issue. Miller began the race as the prohibitive favorite after a dozen years in office but plummeted in the polls as he was hammered on abortion. ``If NARAL hadn't been out there, we would have had Tom Miller as the candidate,'' said Shelley Bain of the Iowa NARAL affiliate. Branstad and Tauke discounted the role of abortion in the outcome. ``Tom Miller waffled all over the court,'' Branstad said. ``You won't find me doing that.'' Tauke said voters in Iowa are sophisticated and unlikely to cast their ballots on a single issue. ``Essentially, the Miller campaign didn't give people a reason to vote for him,'' he said. Republican Sen. Charles Grassley, who is not up for re-election this year, said only hard-core activists are moved by the abortion issue. ``Those are really far-out people and they represent about 10 percent to 15 percent of the electorate,'' he said. But pro-choice advocates point to other signs the state's electorate is on their side. They say polls find more than 60 percent of those surveyed identify with the pro-choice label. They also point to the victory of pro-choice Democrat Eric Tabor in a congressional primary in Tauke's district. In addition, a series of attempts to enact restrictions in the legislature failed by 2-1 margins last winter, a good barometer of public opinion, they say. Republicans reject the suggestion abortion will cause them problem this fall. ``If abortion hurts Tom Tauke or Terry Branstad, it will be because they fail to talk about other issues in a way that moves people,'' said Iowa Republican Party spokesman Mike Day.

DOC.HEAD: Irvine's Liberal Era Ends as Activist Mayor is Ousted
DOC.TEXT: This affluent Republican city in conservative Orange County has ended a strange political marriage, ousting a Democratic mayor schooled in '60s activism who put the environment, gay rights and foreign affairs on the municipal agenda. The days of blaring national headlines like ``Irvine and the Ozone: City Sets Out to Save the Planet'' are over. But Larry Agran has left his mark on the community. Agran, 45, a 12-year City Councilman who two years ago became the first directly elected mayor of the city of 110,000, lost to Councilwoman Sally Anne Sheridan by 860 votes Tuesday. Previously the mayor was appointed by the council. ``We've been on a very ambitious progressive course,'' Agran said Thursday. ``I think that has political costs associated with it.'' The voters also rejected two of Agran's council allies, restoring a conservative majority. ``He'd lost touch with our community. They felt it was time for a change, to get back to the realities of running city government,'' said Sheridan, 55, a real estate agent elected to the council in 1984. ``They didn't like the city of Irvine being used for an international political agenda.'' ``If the city's name does not get into the paper for the next year, I will not be unhappy,'' she said. Agran, a lawyer educated at Harvard and the University of California at Berkeley during the 1960s, managed to hold power in a Southern California county and city where Republicans outnumber Democrats 2-1. Only three of the county's 29 mayors are registered Democrats. He initially succeeded because his blend of fiscal conservatism and social liberalism appealed to traditional conservatives, said Mark Petracca, an Agran supporter and political science professor at the University of California at Irvine. ``That conservative constituency supported his intention to use government to do social good,'' Petracca said. Agran's approach to social change was broad, even global, in scope as he tried to set an example for municipal activism. He successfully fought for environmental measures ranging from curbside recycling and open-space preservation to stringent restrictions on the use of chloroflurocarbons and other industrial chemicals that damage the ozone. He pursued an ambitious mass-transit plan focusing on a countywide monorail system. The $250 million proposal also provided a model for shifting the defense industry toward civilian projects as military spending decreases, Agran said. Under Agran, the city aggressively pursued business and cultural ties with foreign countries, particularly those in the Pacific Rim. And the mayor made a postwar trip to Vietnam to try to reunite five Irvine-area Vietnamese families with relatives lost after the fall of Saigon. Some in Irvine, including Sheridan, accused Agran of ignoring ``pothole projects'' in favor of ``esoteric'' international issues. Agran denied that and said he was advancing issues that concerned residents on both a personal and political level. A human rights ordinance enacted under Agran stirred opposition. Christian fundamentalists and others opposed the ordinance because it barred discrimination against homosexuals, among other groups. Voters in November removed the protection for gay people, despite Agran's call for tolerance. Petracca suggested that such political controversy simply doesn't fit the nature of the community, which the 1980 Census showed to have a median income 37 percent above the county's $22,802. ``Most of the people want to be left alone to their little house and plot of grass. That's why they moved to Irvine,'' Petracca said. ``You want political action, you move to Chicago.'' Agran also said he believes a $25,000, last-minute mailer, sent out by a county GOP organization, tipped the balance. The mailer included a reprint of an article that labeled him the ``Evil Emperor of Irvine.'' Sheridan said some of Agran's programs were valuable and probably would remain. Agran said another run for office is unlikely in the short term, but he had no regrets about his activist tenure. ``I think in many respects we have changed the political landscape,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Disputes Over Price Supports to Get Public Airing
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee is going public this week with its disputes over price supports in the 1990 farm bill. Meanwhile, the counterpart panel in the House is wrapping up its version of the legislation that sets agriculture policy for the next five years with completion of the conservation section of the bill. Both debates are scheduled for Tuesday. The House plan is to have a bill on the floor by June 25. The Senate is not as optimistic. The big stumbling block in the Senate is over commodities. Most problems with other sections were resolved in closed meetings between the Democratic and Republican staffs and quickly approved in open sessions of the committee. When the staffs couldn't resolve the commodity price support problems, committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., appointed a working group of himself and Sens. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb.; David Pryor, D-Ark.; Richard Lugar, R-Ind.; Bob Dole, R-Kan.; and Thad Cochran, R-Miss. When that group couldn't solve the problems, Leahy decided to settle the matter through voting in open session. ``I think we will end up getting a bill reported out,'' Kerrey said last Friday. ``It won't be what Lugar wants. It won't be exactly what I want.'' Kerrey took the lead among the Democrats in the committee who proposed increasing price supports by 1 percent in 1991 and allowing other increases in the four subsequent years based on inflation rates. Lugar's proposal represented the Bush administration's position that price supports should be frozen at 1990 levels. The House bill also calls for a freeze. Kerrey said his proposal would cost $13 billion in 1991, even though ``we only got $10.6 billion from the Budget Committee.'' He said Leahy had told him he wouldn't take a bill to the full committee unless it had support of all the Democrats on the panel, was within the budget and could bring in some of the Republicans. ``I think we have every disagreement settled except for the loan rates,'' Kerrey said. Lugar told reporters early last week that he would not accept anything other than a freeze in target prices and loan rates. He said if Democrats wanted to make an issue of it, they would find themselves in a floor battle that could lead to a one-year extension of current law instead of a five-year program. ``The administration wants a one-year extension,'' Kerrey said. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has said repeatedly that an extension would be acceptable because international trade talks to be completed in December, could create a need for a change in support policies anyway.

Animal rights activists would end up in federal prison if they attack farms or research labs, under legislation up for a vote this week in the House Agriculture Committee. ``It brings the full weight of our laws against the extremists who have gotten out of control,'' said Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, sponsor of the measure, which is similar to a bill approved by the Senate last November. He said it applies only to crimes considered ``terrorist'' attacks. He wants it included in the 1990 farm bill. The measure applies to facilities or premises where an animal is kept for food, fiber production, agriculture, research, testing or education. It makes it a federal crime to: _Disrupt the activities of the premises. _Steal or damage property or animals. _Enter a facility with the intent to commit a violation. _Remain in a facility despite notice that entry was forbidden. Violators could be fined up to $10,000 and jailed for up to three years, or both. Any person harmed by a violation may recover actual and consequential damages and court costs. ``No matter how good and righteous you think your cause is, you do not have the right to take the law into your own hands,'' said Stenholm. ``Those who choose to disrupt lawful agricultural and scientific research activities through violent means should face legal sanctions that are commensurate with their actions.'' Rep. Charles Rose, D-N.C., another member of the House Agriculture Committee, has proposed an amendment to the Animal Welfare Act that would set fines but no jail time for damage to research facilities or farms. It also includes a provision that allows for temporary removal of an animal from a research facility to document whether the animal is being treated properly according to existing law. If a person who has broken into a facility proves that animals are being mistreated, the facility would have to reimburse the person who committed the break-in for any court costs. Rose's bill also allows people to file lawsuits on behalf of animals.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Case Revives Charge of `Selective Prosecution'
With PM-Barry Trial Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Almost as though it were an obvious fact, some blacks questioned as Marion Barry's potential jurors have been telling a judge they believe the Washington mayor would not be on trial if he were white. Barry's arrest in an elaborate FBI sting operation revived a charge that prosecutors systematically go after successful black politicians. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, estimates that 80 percent of the black people in Washington believe that to be true. He puts himself in that category, too. Mary R. Sawyer, assistant professor of religious studies at Iowa State University, has studied the issue. In a 1987 report, she listed 77 black public officials who she says were subject to selective prosecution or some other form of harassment. Among those she lists: Mayors Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, Coleman Young of Detroit and Richard Arrington of Birmingham, Ala.; former Mayors Carl Stokes of Cleveland, Kenneth Gibson of Newark, N.J.; and Charles Evers of Fayette, Miss.; Reps. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y.; Harold Ford, D-Tenn.; and Louis Stokes, D-Ohio; and former Reps. Shirley Chisholm, D-N.Y. and Charles Diggs, D-Mich. But as often as the accusation is made, prosecutors deny it. ``We follow the evidence wherever it leads, regardless of position, race, party affiliation or other identifying factors,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said last January. Last month, he said ``no one would be more disturbed than I would be'' if it were proven that the Justice Department engaged in racially motivated selective prosecutions. In court, U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens suggested that the government went after Barry because he is a role model in a city that last year saw 438 homicides, most of them drug-related. Barry's arrest is ``a personal tragedy'' Stephens said, but ``narcotics abuse is also a tragedy for this city ... not a victimless crime.'' Obliquely, Barry himself makes the charge, too. ``The prosecutors have been dipping and dabbling in the politics of Washington for a long time,'' he said in May, and complained he had been ``hounded, harassed, vilified, slandered.'' The view that Barry had been singled out was expressed by some potential jurors as the mayor's trial on drug and perjury charges started last week. ``It seems like that some people are made to go through a little more than others,'' one potential juror told U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. ``They televised this too much, talked about it too much. ... I think race had a lot to do with it, as far as giving him a hard time.'' Jackson asked if a white mayor would have been spared investigation and prosecution under similar circumstances. ``Exactly,'' she replied. She was accepted as a member of the jury pool. ``The media can say Barry's lifestyle is not appropriate, but the masses of people perceive that if Marion Barry were white we would not be reading anything about him,'' says Clarence Mitchell III, who served with Barry in the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in the 1960s. Mitchell says he also is a victim of selective prosecution. A former Maryland state legislator, he says he was investigated 19 times in 24 years in public life before being tried with his brother, Michael, and convicted on charges of accepting a bribe. He is appealing. At the sentencing, their mother, Juanita Jackson Mitchell, alluded to the brothers' claim that they were victims of an FBI vendetta. ``My sons are casualties on the road to freedom,'' she said. The NAACP's Hooks, in an interview, was careful to avoid passing judgment on Barry. But he drew an analogy: ``If everyone is going 80 miles an hour on the highway, and you're doing 70 and the cops stop you, you've got to wonder.'' Joseph Agne, a consultant to the National Council of Churches, suggests that white prosecutors go after blacks as ``one way to get around the gains from the Voting Rights Act.'' Its enactment led to the election of thousands of black public officials. Last year the church group, in a resolution, deplored what it saw as a ``concerted effort on the part of law enforcement officials to discredit and remove African American elected officials from office.'' But Richard A. Samp, chief counsel for the conservative Washington Legal Foundation, says an increase in investigations of black officeholders was inevitable. Corruption generally occurs at the local level, Samp says, and that's where blacks generally have been winning elections. And Louis Michael Seidman, law professor at Georgetown University, points to a 19th century Supreme Court decision that selective prosecution _ to make an example of a conspicuous lawbreaker, for example _ is permissible, as long as it is not based on such things as race or religion. Barry's only recourse, now that he has admitted he used crack cocaine at a hotel last Jan. 18, is to persuade a jury that he was singled out, Seidman says. ``In reality, that is his defense,'' says Seidman. ``The question he wants the jury to think about is whether the government was conducting a vendetta against him because he was black.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington Proves a Bad Example in Head Count
DOC.TEXT: The directors of the 1990 U.S. Census can, on a clear day, see one of their biggest nightmares from their office windows. Residents of the nation's capital are down near the bottom of the list when it comes to doing their census duty. They're behind every state and are 29th out of the country's 32 biggest cities in cooperating with the head count. It looks like the national drive to convince people it's their civic duty to fill those census forms out went straight past the federal government's back yard. ``This is a world capital city,'' John Connelly, an assistant to the director of the census, said last week. ``There are people from all over the world here. You have a lot of immigrants, a lot of Hispanics in the greater Washington area.'' Language differences and distrust of the federal government are among the major barriers census officials have cited in getting people to do the decennial task. ``Most of our major cities were low,'' said Russell Davis, a spokesman in the Census Bureau's promotion office. But hardly any so low as the District of Columbia, which also boasts the nation's highest concentration of government workers. As of June 5, the Census Bureau reported a 76 percent response rate from the district. And that followed door-to-door questioning by census counters after only 57 percent of the city's households mailed their forms in. The bureau reported a national 91 percent response rate as of last week. Every state was above 80 percent and Iowans were the closest to putting the counting behind them with a 97.8 percent response. ``I wouldn't say the district is especially disappointing,'' said Connelly. ``But, sure, there are probably comments going around that a lot of people here work for the federal government and ought to know what the census is for.'' Kay Hixson, a spokeswoman for Mayor Marion Barry, said the city has spent some $400,000 this spring on the census. ``We're obviously disappointed the response is not what we had hoped,'' she said. But she said Washington's unique population makeup may actually be hurting the census effort. ``We have a substantial transient population, with congressional people, embassies, international banks. These are things where people move in and out and I would suspect that often they're not focused on things critical to the community,'' said Hixson. Other cities are having problems, however. Boston was the worst of the big cities with a 71.7 percent response rate as of a week ago. Phoenix, Ariz., was next at 73.4 percent and New York City was at 74.1 percent. In contrast, Detroit reported a 93.4 percent response rate. San Antonio, which has a large Hispanic population, was also at 93.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Civil War Ironclad Said Fragile But Still Intact
DOC.TEXT: The 128-year-old wreckage of the Civil War ironclad Monitor is fragile but still intact, the government said as it cleared the way for photographers to venture to the ship's Atlantic grave. For the first time in 11 years, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is permitting research dives to the ship, which sank in a gale 16 miles off Cape Hatteras, N.C., in 1862. Armed with a NOAA permit, photographer and author Rod Farb of Cedar Grove, N.C., arrived at the site with a film crew last week, beating out a scuba-diving rival. Farb and Gary Gentile of Philadelphia had vied to become the first to dive to the ship since French explorer Jacques Cousteau did it in 1979. Gentile still plans to dive to the ship in several weeks, but it won't be the same, said his attorney, Peter Hess. ``Do you remember the second guy to cross the Atlantic?'' he said. Gentile had filed 11 permit applications and written more than 50 letters to NOAA since 1984 seeking permission to photograph the wreck. He won his Monitor permit first but decided to wait until the weather improved at the end of June to make the trip, Hess said, Cousteau's expedition was hampered by bad weather and poor visibility, and little or no usable footage was produced. But NOAA said Farb was blessed with good conditions when he and his crew made their first dive at the end of last week. NOAA, part of the Commerce Department, is responsible for safeguarding the wreckage. Accompanied by a NOAA representative, Farb was expected to remain at the site for several days, and the agency said it did not expect him to release any footage right away. NOAA refused to allow Monitor dives after Cousteau's trip, saying the 220-foot depth posed ``a serious and unreasonable risk'' that its own divers would not take. Meanwhile, some private divers _ fearing the wreck was in danger of collapse _ lobbied the agency to permit dives before the historic ship was lost. NOAA reversed its position after one of its administrative law judges ruled last November that the agency exaggerated safety concerns, and that ``a significant number of trained scuba divers'' frequently descend 220 feet. Before permitting Farb's dive, NOAA researchers disclosed Friday that they descended to the wreck in a submarine on June 1-2 to make a ``visual record'' to ensure that artifacts are not tampered with later. ``The best word to describe the condition is that we believe it's stable,'' said Tim Keeney, NOAA director of ocean and coastal resources. ``Certainly the hull of the vessel is not made of thick metal and there are parts that have caved in. However, there is armor plating surrounding the vessel, and that is almost totally intact on the port side.'' The ship's gun turret ``looks like it's in pretty good shape,'' Keeney said. The Monitor sank after a celebrated battle with the Confederate ship Merrimack in 1862. It was discovered by researchers in 1973. The Merrimack, renamed the Virginia, was destroyed by its crew to keep it from being captured by the Union. The Monitor appears fragile, said Irv Garrison, a NOAA marine archaeologist who was on the submarine. ``Time is one thing,'' he said. ``But she's also right in the area of a shipping lane, and every destroyer that went by may have dropped a load on her. She might have been depth-charged, which would be a ironic fate for an old Civil War boat.''

DOC.HEAD: Better Living Seen in Third World from Extralegal Short Cuts
DOC.TEXT: They used to be called scofflaws, tax evaders, black marketeers and worse, but they're getting new dignity now as ``the informal sector,'' and they could be one key to better life for people in the Third World. They include a wide range of enterprising people. There's the little boy in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, who buys a package of cigarettes and sells them one by one on a street corner. He pays no tax or license fee and makes a small profit. There are also the 70 families of squatters in a Latin American capital who stole their electricity when the power company refused to sell it. A study published last week by the private World Resources Institute with two United Nations agencies pulled together much of the investigation done on what economists have dubbed the informal sector. It said many planners now see it as probably the greatest source of new jobs in Third World cities. In the year 2000, Mexico City is expected to have more than 27 million people and Bombay, India, more than 15 million. That gives plenty of room for volunteer groups that in many places already help supply drinking water, sanitation, small loans and even recycling services. By the standards of industrialized countries, the pay or profit is low. But even in what the World Bank calls upper-middle-income countries, such as Brazil or Malaysia, the average income is around $2,000 a year, one-tenth the U.S. average. The World Bank, biggest source of aid to the Third World, found the electricity thieves in an unnamed Latin American capital. It said the leader of a squatter community told of going to the manager of the power company and being informed that it could not sell to them. ``In the end he decided to be indulgent with us, in exchange for our promise that we would not abuse our arrangement by `going too far' with domestic connections,'' the leader was quoted as saying. ``The fact is that we do not pay for electricity now. It is free, and we have been able to light our streets, our school and our homes. If there were anything else that we needed and if the government were unwilling to give it to us, then we would just take it without authorization.'' A study published by the Johns Hopkins University Press told of shantytown dwellers who collect waste in Montevideo, Uruguay, and separate the types for recycling. But the necessary washing of plastics takes too much labor. So they farm out that part of the job to small family enterprises that can do it more cheaply. The same study reported that in Niamey, Niger, tinsmiths and blacksmiths recycled scrap metal and made 30,000 stoves in two years. The efficient stoves cut the consumption of scarce fuel wood. It estimated that in most Third World countries the informal sector includes 30 percent to 70 percent of the working population.

DOC.HEAD: March Organizers Claim Movement Milestone
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The mobilization of thousands of people to march for animals marks a milestone in the animal rights movement, activists say. ``There is no question we are making progress,'' organizer Tom Regan said Sunday after a rally which featured celebrities such as singer Grace Slick and ``Superman'' movie star Christopher Reeve. Regan, a professor of philosophy at North Carolina State University, said the animal rights movement is one that advocates lifestyle changes. Regan, for instance, does not eat meat. U.S. Capitol Police estimated 24,000 people attended the first ``March for the Animals,'' along with a rally on the steps of the Capitol. Organizers claimed more than 50,000 people from around the country showed up for the one-mile march down Pennsylvania Avenue to the Capitol. Marchers chanted ``Animal Rights _ Now.'' Many carried banners and placards with pictures and slogans saying things such as ``Animals Are Not for Wearing,'' ``Fur Is Dead,'' and ``Animals Have Rights, Too.'' Some brought their dogs. Peter Linck of the National Alliance for Animal Legislation said the rally was a show of unity among diverse groups that advocate a range of programs from saving elephants in the wild and banning furs to ending use of animals in medical research and changing the way veal is produced. The most controversial position of animal rights activists deals with their opposition to use of animals in medical research _ a view the nation's top health officials say is misguided, out of step with the position of a majority of responsible members of the scientific community and a potential threat to medical advances. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan has criticized animal rights advocates who use violence and intimidation to block testing of animals. ``They are on the wrong side of morality,'' he said last week. Sullivan said some of the greatest advances in medicine, such as the cure for polio, never would have been achieved had animals not been used in tests. Dr. Frederick Goodwin, head of the U.S. Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, said in an interview Sunday that animals provide the ``critical linchpin between the petri dish and people.'' Tests using animals are employed about 20 percent of the time by biomedical researchers, he said. Without those tests, advances in finding a cure for AIDS, for instance, would stop, he said. But Slick, once the lead singer for the Jefferson Starship group, said she was opposed to animal testings in laboratories. ``I'm for all angles of animal rights,'' Slick said. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., head of the informal Congressional Friends of Animals group, said he opposes the ``unnecessary, duplicative and cruel use of animals in medical and other areas.'' Barbara Huffman of Freemont, Wis., president of the American Veal Association, said she was angry about allegations that veal producers are cruel to animals. Activists claim the calves are chained and force-fed drug-laden food before their slaughter at age four months. ``We are producing a safe and plentiful food supply,'' she said. ``We provide the best care for our animals that we can.'' Several bills pending in Congress deal with the animal rights issue. Among then is one to protect animals in testing of cosmetics, one to prohibit the confinement of veal calves in small crates and another to end hunting and trapping on wildlife refuges. A separate bill would impose jail terms on activists who attack farms or research labs. Among the groups participating in the march were the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the U.S. Humane Society and the Doris Day Animal League.

DOC.HEAD: Community Protesting Teen-ager's Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Each Friday they march, circling the front steps of the courthouse with signs protesting the first-degree murder conviction of a black teen-ager by an all-white jury. In Massachusetts, that conviction means life without parole, almost unheard of in a homicide stemming from a street fight. ``There's nothing on either side to suggest that it was anything but happenstance that they came together,'' said David Hoose, the attorney for Charles Fryar. The black 18-year-old was convicted April 3 of stabbing 21-year-old Eric Palmer during a confrontation last year between black youths and white students from Springfield College. Hoose blamed the fight on alcohol and hotheaded youth. The conviction galvanized blacks in this city of 150,000, sparking two big rallies, a fund-raising effort that has netted more than $7,000 and lunchtime vigils outside the Hampden County Hall of Justice every Friday by up to a dozen people. ``I think people are finally tired of the double standard that's handed out at the Hall of Justice,'' said Norma Baker, a leader of the African-American Coalition.
