The Supreme Judicial Court, in a move unrelated to the Fryar case, has ordered a study of racial and ethnic bias in the state's legal system. The vigils have been going on for about six weeks. The Rev. Edward Harding said he plans to keep appearing at them until at least Sept. 11, the trial date for Lester Jowers, the other person charged in Palmer's slaying. Coalition members want to keep the controversy alive while Fryar's appeal moves through the courts. ``We expect that we're going to have to do this over the next couple of years,'' Baker said. The coalition, a group of directors of local social service agencies, has focused on the jury selection system, maintaining that there are not enough minorities on Hampden County juries. The minority population of Springfield is about 30 percent, but that drops to about 6 percent countywide. Paul Carr, state jury commissioner, defended the Massachusetts system. State law, he said, requires cities to conduct a census of everyone over 17. Those names are fed into a computer, and jury pools are drawn at random. Before budget cutbacks forced the adoption of a mail census, the Springfield Election Commission used off-duty police officers or postal workers to compile names by going door-to-door. Coalition members said off-duty police officers may intimidate some minorities. In the Fryar case, only two prospective jurors were black, Hoose said. Prosecutor William T. Walsh Jr., who has since left the district attorney's office for private practice, said he thought the verdict was fair and that a different racial makeup on the jury would have made no difference. Fryar supporters said they're not claiming that a black jury would have let him off lightly. But, said Hoose, ``an all-white jury is going to relate more on a subtle level to the white students who testified.'' The lawyer said he did not argue in court that if jurors believed Fryar guilty, they should convict on a charge less serious than first-degree murder because he was bound to follow his client's plea of innocence. ``There's still a fall-back position (for appeal) which is, of course, even if he did do it, it's manslaughter and second-degree murder at the worst,'' Hoose said.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Involved in Romance With 23-Year-Old Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES last graf as extraneous.
DOC.TEXT: A hospitalized Elizabeth Taylor has a new boyfriend _ a 23-year-old who is lifting the actress' spirits and has her ``blooming again, like a rose,'' a spokeswoman says. Miss Taylor, 58, is fighting severe depression as she recovers from pneumonia at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. Doctors on Sunday performed an abdominal biopsy, finding no new lung infection, said Miss Taylor's spokeswoman Chen Sam. Miss Taylor is expected to be released from the hospital within two weeks. The actress decided to make public her relationship with Julian Lee Hobbs of Lake Orion, a suburb of Detroit, so he can be at her side, said Ms. Sam. ``It's a very romantic story,'' the spokeswoman said. Hobbs and Miss Taylor have been involved since 1988, said Lisa Flowers, another spokeswoman. They will spend a short time at the actress' Bel-Air home before traveling to Switzerland for a long rest, Ms. Flowers said. ``She is very depressed. It's a very sad situation,'' said Ms. Flowers. ``Julian was out of the picture for so long, and now he is back in. She is blooming again, like a rose.'' No other details about Hobbs were released. The star of ``Butterfield 8,'' ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and more than 50 other films has been married seven times. Apparently out of the picture is Miss Taylor's latest reported love interest, truck driver Larry Fortensky. Ms. Flowers said security people removed him last week from Miss Taylor's Bel-Air home. Sunday's biopsy, which took less than an hour using a fiber optic device, came two months after Miss Taylor's hospitalization for a near-fatal bout with pneumonia. Her condition was complicated by a yeast infection of the blood. ``Maybe if he (Julian) had been in the picture two months ago, things would have been different. Julian is what makes her happy,'' Ms. Flowers said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,540.18, down 453.11 points, or 1.37 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Reject Free-Market Shock Therapy in Vote for Fujimori
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: In giving political newcomer Alberto Fujimori a landslide presidential victory, the people of this economically crippled nation rejected the free-market shock therapy advocated by novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. Fujimori, an agronomist and the son of Japanese immigrants, captured Sunday's runoff by 13 to 19 points, according to exit polls conducted by independent firms. Official returns were not expected for at least three weeks because of poor communication with mountain and jungle regions. Vargas Llosa, a celebrated novelist, conceded defeat three hours after polls closed. He told supporters he wished Fujimori ``success in the difficult responsibility the Peruvian people have placed on him.'' He urged Peruvians to put the bitterly fought campaign behind them. Vargas Llosa had been the early favorite. He won the most votes in the first round of voting on April 8 _ but not the majority needed for election. Fujimori, a 51-year-old former university rector, ran a shoe-string campaign against Vargas Llosa's well-heeled Democratic Front coalition. A political unknown just months ago, Fujimori gained the support of Peru's poor, Protestant evangelists and leftists opposed to Vargas Llosa's plans to privatize state industries and lift price controls. He takes charge of a country where four in five people lack a steady job, annual inflation is 2,000 percent and violence related to the Maoist-inspired Shining Path insurgency has claimed more than 18,500 lives in the last decade. ``I realize it will be a titanic task,'' Fujimori said soberly Sunday night, addressing reporters. He invited all political parties to participate in his government in areas where agreements could be reached. Fujimori's critics accused him of ties to the Aprista Party of President Alan Garcia. Many people blame the populist policies of Garcia, who by law could not run for re-election, for Peru's desperate economic situation. Fujimori, who begins his five-year term on July 28 in a country weathering its worst economic crisis of the century, has said little about the makeup of his administration. He has said, however, that he would not appoint members of the Aprista Party to his Cabinet. Vargas Llosa, 54, had pledged harsh austerity measures to revive the economy while Fujimori advocated continued price controls and subsidies for basic goods and services. Fujimori said his government would stress economic development over military and police repression as the best way to fight both leftist guerrillas and cocaine trafficking. He did not indicate where the money would come from for economic development. The Peruvian treasury is $100 million in the red. Peru is the world's main source of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. The U.S. government is pressuring Peru to reduce its coca production, and has offered to send U.S. soldiers to train Peruvian troops in jungle warfare methods to fight guerrillas. Fujimori said he shared Vargas Llosa's view that Peru ``must be reinserted into the world financial community'' and said he would seek to renegotiate Peru's $20 billion foreign debt. Garcia suspended foreign debt payments early in his government and international lending agencies eventually cut off credit to Peru. Many attributed Vargas Llosa's loss to a multi-million dollar media campaign that angered people in this country of 22 million people where the average annual income is $900 and the minimum wage is $45 a month. Vargas Llosa is widely associated by the South American country's indigenous and mixed-race majority with the European-descended coastal elite. Thousands of campaign supporters paraded and celebrated early today outside the run-down headquarters of Fujimori's Change 90 party in downtown Lima. The independent polling firm Apoyo gave Fujimori 51.1 percent of the vote to 37.8 percent for Vargas Llosa, with 11.1 percent blank and null votes. POP, another independent polling firm, showed Fujimori with 56 percent and Vargas Llosa 36.5 percent. POP put blank and null votes at 7.5 percent. Nearly 10 million Peruvians were registered to vote, and the law requires them to cast ballots. As the polls opened Sunday, armored helicopters crisscrossed Lima's skies. Tanks and troop carriers patrolled the streets of the capital, home to about 7 million people. Little violence was reported around the country on Sunday despite threats by the Shining Path to disrupt the elections. At least 10 bombs exploded Sunday in Huancayo, a highland farming center 120 miles east of Lima. Police said that one, placed by guerrillas at a polling station, killed one person and wounded eight. In a separate attack, rebels shot and killed three brothers. Police said a note was found on one of the bodies that said, ``This is how informers die.'' Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, said Sunday that he would seek improved relations with countries of the Pacific basin. ``I understand that in the land of my ancestors there is great interest in my election,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Defied Odds to Rocket to Peru's Presidency
With PM-Peru, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Four months ago, Alberto Fujimori was a complete newcomer to politics. Those who did know the soft-spoken, 51-year-old agricultural engineer knew him as the former rector of the respected National Agrarian University. Now, this son of Japanese immigrants has astounded Peruvians with a meteoric rise from obscurity. They call it ``Fujimania.'' Fujimori sold his house, car, and tractor just to raise campaign funds. He avoided specifics, speaking mainly of broad social goals like improved health care and revitalized industry. He sometimes resorted to attention-getting gimmicks, such as dressing like a samurai warrior for news photographers. Whatever the formula, it worked. Fujimori claimed to be the only candidate truly independent of ``professional politicians.'' But during the campaign, he showed political skill honed during his years of running a university in a country where universities are highly politicized. Fujimori is the oldest of five children, the son of a tailor from the southern Japanese island of Kyushu who came to Peru in 1934 to work its coastal cotton plantations. His father worked at various jobs, including an upholstery shop he opened in Lima. The family lost the business during a boycott of Japanese businesses during World War II. In 1960, Fujimori earned a degree in agricultural engineering from the National Agrarian University, where he later taught mathematics. He served as the school's rector from 1984 to 1989. He did post-graduate work at the University of Wisconsin and the University of Strasburg in France. Fujimori got a peek at the circles of power by serving for two years as an agricultural adviser to the outgoing government of President Alan Garcia. He speaks Spanish, Japanese, English, French and German. He describes himself as studious, introverted and lacking all ``common vices.'' He says work is his hobby, that he devotes 12 to 13 hours a day to it. Along with their four children, Fujimori and his wife, Susana Higuchi, had been running their own three-acre farm before the race. In his brief time in the political spotlight, Fujimori has been surrounded by controversy. Critics say the agriculture university went into sharp decline under his leadership. He has been charged with evading taxes on the sale of various properties and with illegally benefitting from a land-distribution program designed to aid peasants. In addition, his close connections with Peru's evangelical community prompted the country's Roman Catholic Church to take the unusual step of voicing support for the man he defeated, celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. Fujimori has been accused of having close ties to the ruling Aprista Party and critics claim he is a ``Trojan Horse'' through which Garcia will retain power. The large majority of Peru's 60,000-member Japanese immigrant community supported Vargas Llosa. But Fujimori was overwhelmingly supported by millions of Peru's poor, who account for more than 50 percent this country of 22 million. ``The poor needed an alternative to Vargas Llosa and the failed policies of the present government,'' said Jorge Castillo, of the private polling company Datum. ``Fujimori is a candidate invented by the electorate.'' Fujimori has compared his campaign strategy to the martial arts. ``You take advantage of the forces of the other _ boom boom _ wherever they lead,'' he told The Associated Press in an interview during the campaign, slicing his hand through an imaginary brick. Thus, he attacked Vargas Llosa's free-market platform while remaining vague about many of his own ideas. Usually dressed in a three-piece suit, Fujimori appeared stiff and serious among potential voters, but they warmed to him and his promises of discipline and hard work. He says his political movement, called simply Change 90, is an ``expression of people who are tired of the old, corrupt political parties and who just want to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Suicide-Machine Victim Mourned by Family, Friends
LaserPhoto PD6
DOC.TEXT: The woman who took her life with the press of a button was called a ``pioneer in the battle for death with dignity'' at a memorial service she planned as carefully as her suicide. ``To die a little later, or a little sooner, does not matter,'' the Rev. Alan G. Deale said Sunday at the service for Janet Elaine Adkins. What matters is ``to live bravely, to love wisely, to see how beautiful the trees are, and even the sea _ to enjoy the world,'' said her minister. Mrs. Adkins, a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease, selected the music and speakers for the service before traveling to Michigan to end her life by means of a drug-injecting machine built by medical maverick Dr. Jack Kevorkian. Kevorkian, who is under investigation by prosecutors and medical regulators, did not attend the service. An exceptional woman in life, ``Janet would become famous in death,'' Deale told friends and family members at the First Unitarian Church of Portland. ``The public attention that her death has received is an indication of the level of interest in this phenomenon,'' he said, describing her as a ``pioneer in the battle for death with dignity.'' The minister said he believed she had the right to her decision. In 1988, the Unitarian Universalist Association adopted a resolution acknowledging circumstances in which the dignity of life could be compromised and supporting an individual's right to choose death. ``Janet loved life, but she didn't fear death,'' said Judy Humiston, one of three friends who remembered Adkins' love of good conversation, philosophy, music, travel, teaching and tennis. Family members occasionally had tears in their eyes, but the spirit of the hourlong ceremony was joyful. Deale said that was Mrs. Adkins' wish. Carol Rehmke recalled with a smile that Adkins loved to win. ``Janet taught me to play chess and we played by mail,'' said Rehmke. ``She won the first game and I won the second. And we never played the third game.'' A string quartet played a selection by the Russian composer Alexander Borodin. A string duo performed the pop song ``When I Need You.'' Adkins is survived by her husband, Ron; their adult sons, Neil, Norman and Ronald; three grandchildren, and her mother.

DOC.HEAD: Comparing Texas Spill With Alaskan Disaster
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The supertanker burning in the Gulf of Mexico carried more than three times the oil spilled by the Exxon Valdez off Alaska last year. But authorities said that if the Mega Borg sank, it might not cause as big a catastrophe. Two key differences: The Mega Borg's cargo was light crude, which disperses much more rapidly than the heavy crude carried by the Exxon Valdez; and fire is consuming the Mega Borg's oil. The Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil _ about one-fifth of the 987-foot ship's cargo _ when it ran aground on Bligh Reef in Prince William Sound, 25 miles from the port of Valdez, on March 24, 1989. It was the nation's worst oil spill. More than 1,100 miles of Alaska shoreline were soiled. Thousands of birds, mammals and other wildlife were killed. The Mega Borg was carrying 38 million gallons of light crude when it was wracked by explosions and fire on Saturday about 57 miles southeast of Galveston, Texas. At first, little oil spilled, but five powerful explosions Sunday sent blazing crude pouring into the Gulf. The Mega Borg was listing and apparently in greater danger of sinking than the Exxon Valdez was. The fire, however, appeared to be consuming much of its oil. ``It causes some air pollution, but that dissipates,'' said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson. ``What would be worse would be for it to sit on the surface and drift toward shore.'' Even if that happened, the light crude would disperse much more rapidly than heavy crude, Coast Guard Capt. Tom Greene said. A spill about one mile long north of the vessel and one about 20 miles long to the south were visible Sunday evening. Officials estimated the slicks contained 7,000 gallons of oil. Currents and winds were expected to push the oil toward a 150-to 200-mile stretch of Texas coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi. But Greene said inshore currents could keep the spill washing ashore. If it reached shore, however, the spill could jeopardize a wildlife refuge, salt marshes, oyster reefs and other crucial habitat, environmentalists said. ``I hate the thought of it,'' said Brandt Mannchen of the Sierra Club. ``The entire Galveston Bay is extremely valuable for both recreational fishermen and commercial fishermen,'' said Alan Allen, executive director of the Sportsmen Conservationists of Texas. A November 1979 spill in Galveston Bay was in some ways comparable to both the Valdez spill and the Mega Borg blast. The tanker Burmah Agate collided with a tanker and up to 10.7 million gallons of oil spilled _ but much of it burned off before reaching shore.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Susan Saint James, who co-starred with Jane Curtin on CBS' ``Kate and Allie,'' has given birth to a boy. Saint James, 43, had an 8-pound, 14-ounce baby Sunday, said Richard Bisi, a spokesman at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital. He said mother and child were doing fine. This is Saint James' third child with her husband, former ``Saturday Night Live'' producer Dick Ebersol. She has two children from a previous marriage. The couple plans to name the baby Edward Bright Ebersol. Among other TV roles, Saint James, who lives in Litchfield, starred in ``McMillan and Wife'' with Rock Hudson from 1971 to 1977 and won a best supporting actress Emmy playing an offbeat secretary in ``The Name of the Game,'' which ran from 1968 to 1971.

President Guillero Endara says he loves three things in this world: God, the Panamanian people and his new bride. Endara, 54, married 23-year-old Ana Mae Diaz in a two-hour, Roman Catholic ceremony Sunday at Metropolitan Cathedral. Ambassadors of the United States and Latin American and European countries were among the guests. Endara was installed during the invasion of Panama by U.S. forces that overthrew Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. About 250 people waited outside the cathedral in a heavy rain to throw rice at the newlyweds. The couple met at a university rally after Panama's 1989 elections. Endara won that election, but Noriega annulled the results. Endara was widowed a year ago. He has a daughter and a grandson, who was the ring bearer at the ceremony. The president declared that there are three things he loves: ``God, the Panamanian people and Ana Mae.'' Endara wore a black suit, white shirt and gray tie. The bride wore a traditional white gown.

For 17 years Anjelica Huston lived in the limelight of her lover, Jack Nicholson. But now, with Nicholson out of the picture, she is stepping into her own spotlight. Their erratic relationship came to an end last year when Nicholson had an affair with a former waitress, Rebecca Broussard, who had Nicholson's baby in April. Huston, who won an Oscar for her role in ``Prizzi's Honor,'' said her recent screen work has mirrored and helped manage her life. She appeared in ``Crimes and Misdemeanors'' as a woman rejected by her married lover. When she finished ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' in which she plays a woman whose husband has a child by another woman, she went home to the harsh reality of Nicholson's infidelity. ``That very much reflected what was to go on in my life directly after I came back to Los Angeles after the movie. That was pretty close to the bone,'' she said. Huston said she doesn't know if she is ready to be part of a couple again. ``I'm selfish and opinionated,'' she said. ``I think I follow less than I used to. It's hard for me to sit and nod my head at repeated stories anymore.''

Carroll Shelby, designer of the muscle car that bears his name, is doing well after a heart transplant, a spokesman says. ``He's doing fine, according to the hospital's transplant coordinator,'' the spokesman, Glenn Campbell, said Sunday. He said Shelby hasn't been able to get out of bed yet, but ``the recovery is going along normally.'' Shelby, 67, received the heart during a four-hour operation at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Thursday night. No information on the donor was released. Shelby is a three-time U.S. Sports Car driver of the year and designer of the Shelby Cobra. He also worked as a consultant for Chrysler Motors on the design of its new Viper sports car. The popular Texan, whose chili recipes have become as famous as his race car designs and auto customizing, suffered from congestive heart failure, Wise said. Shelby had heart surgery in 1973 and 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Rap Group Defy Sheriff, Arrested on Obscenity Charges
LaserPhoto MH2
DOC.TEXT: Members of the raunchy rap group 2 Live Crew became ``martyrs for the First Amendment'' when they were arrested on obscenity charges after a concert, their lawyer says. Band leader Luther ``Luke Skyywalker'' Campbell and Chris ``Fresh Kid Ice'' Wongwon were arrested by more than a dozen sheriff's detectives early Sunday. They were charged with singing lyrics from their platinum-selling album, which was ruled obscene by a federal judge in Fort Lauderdale. ``If we had to do it again, we'd do it again,'' Wongwon said before the Miami rappers took the stage in Phoenix on Sunday night. ``We were arrested for playing to adults,'' he said. He added that Broward County (Fla.) Sheriff Nick Navarro has a racial bias against their music. ``It's a black company, it's a black group,'' he said. Campbell, 29, and Wongwon, 26, were freed without bail after two hours in jail. The misdemeanor carries up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. The other band members, Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross and David ``Mr. Mixx'' Hobbs, left Hollywood's Club Futura in a separate car and were not stopped. Navarro said arrest warrants would be issued for them today. ``They could have rapped anything up to and including `White Christmas,''' said sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon. ``As long as they didn't sing anything from `As Nasty As They Wanna Be,' ... they would not have been arrested.'' The rappers' attorney, Bruce Rogow, said the judge's ruling, Friday's arrest of a Fort Lauderdale record store owner who sold the album to undercover agents, and the arrests of band members show Navarro and other anti-obscenity crusaders are ``out of control.'' ``Now everybody's rallying around the First Amendment and, incidentally, around 2 Live Crew,'' Rogow said. ``It's made them martyrs for the First Amendment.'' The arrests gave 2 Live Crew publicity it would not otherwise have received, he said. ``There was a lot of sex _ real sex, nude dancing, prostitution _ going on in Broward County last night,'' Rogow said. ``The criminals must have a had a field day. This is nothing more than talking dirty.'' In Phoenix Sunday night, the band sang two ``clean'' songs at a concert with seven other bands. Concert organizers said the rappers were asked not to perform the X-rated versions. The band refused to go along with a similar request at their adults-only concert Sunday in Hollywood, where they screamed profanities along with a wildly gyrating audience of about 400. Undercover detectives documented the band's performance, which included repeated insults against Navarro. ``We didn't want to create any commotion in there, so I told them to let them get out of there and arrest them away from the premises,'' said Navarro. Deputies pulled over Campbell and Wongwon's car several blocks from the club. Rogow said he believes U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez's ruling Wednesday did not make it illegal to sing the songs in a setting like Club Futura.

DOC.HEAD: Man Regarded as World's Oldest, John Evans, Dies At Age 112
DOC.TEXT: A retired Welsh coal miner who was considered the world's oldest man has died in his sleep at age 112, his daughter-in-law says. John Evans had firmly believed that his longevity was due to not drinking, smoking, swearing or gambling. ``But some part of it is taking hot water in the morning ... (with) a small bit of honey. I've been doing that since I retired,'' he told the British Broadcasting Corp. on his 111th birthday in 1988. Betty Evans said her father-in-law died early Sunday in a chair beside his bed at his cottage in Forest-fach, near Swansea, Wales, after feeling ``a little unwell'' for a few days. The 1990 Guinness Book of Records said Evans was considered the world's oldest living man because he had a birth certificate proving his age. It says the oldest living person whose birth date can be authenticated is a 115-year-old woman, Carrie C. White, born in Gadsden, Fla., on Nov. 18, 1874. She lives in a nursing home in Palatka, Fla. Evans was born on Aug. 19, 1877, when Queen Victoria was on the British throne. He started working in coal mines when he was 13, and only stopped at age 73 because of National Coal Board mandatory retirement rules. Evans was fitted with a pacemaker when he was 108. Doctors at Cardiff Hospital said at the time they thought he was the oldest person to undergo the operation and were astounded when he was able to return home three days later. ``It's given me a new lease of life _ and I don't have to go back to have new batteries put in for another 10 years'' he joked at the time. Evans had a wheelchair but preferred a walking stick. He worked in his garden until he was 95, planting potatoes and other vegetables. Like many Welshmen, he loved to sing. ``I've been doing that since I was a little boy. Going to Sunday school, I'd sing, plenty of it,'' he said in the BBC interview. In 1987, Evans visited London, 190 miles away, to celebrate his 110th birthday. He said he thought of making the trip in 1900 but couldn't afford the $2.50 it cost then for the train ticket. Evans' 79-year-old son, Amwel, had his own explanation for his father's long life. ``My father always had a very lively mind and just loved life,'' he said Sunday. ``I'm sure that had everything to do with his remarkable health. We're all very sad _ but very proud of him today.'' Mrs. Evans, Amwel's wife, said: ``A big gap has been left in our lives. The longer John was with us, the harder it was going to be to say goodbye. Evans lived with Amwel and Betty. He is survived by two other sons and a daughter, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Funeral plans have not been announced. Norris McWhirter, founding editor of the Guinness Book of Records, said Sunday that it is not yet known who succeeds Evans as the oldest man: ``The absolute world record for longevity was held by Shigechiyo Izumi of Japan, who died on February 21, 1986, aged 120 years, 237 days.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Soars, Stocks Plunge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar soared against the Japanese yen today, pushing down share prices across the board on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 154.10 yen, up 1.45 yen from Friday's close of 152.65 yen. It opened at the day's low of 153.35 yen and rose as high as 154.20 yen. Its close was the highest since 154.15 yen on May 11. Traders attributed the dollar's rise to its gain on overseas markets at the end of last week and concern about the governing Liberal Democratic Party's loss of an upper house by-election on Sunday. The dollar still is being helped by continued unrest in the Soviet Union and uncertainties about the impact of German unification, they added. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 453.11 points, or 1.37 percent, closing at 32,540.18. Dealers said the yen's weakness against the dollar and the governing party's defeat in Sunday's by-election discouraged investors. ``Negative factors pulled down bond prices and Nikkei index futures, leading to a sharp deline in share prices as well,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. A trader with Nomura Securities Co. said Friday's 34.95-point decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in New York further discouraged market players. He said that while shares prices were lower almost all across the board, large capital shares, such as heavy industry and steel issues, were particularly weak. The governing party's defeat in the by-election triggered concern in the market that it has not fully recovered from the distrust caused by recent money and sex scandals and the introduction of an unpopular tax. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.18 points at 5 p.m. from Friday's 87.78-point finish. The yield rose to 7.140 percent from Friday's 7.015 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Major Spill Feared Off Cape Cod
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: A 90-foot tear discovered on the bottom of a cruise ship threatened a spill of 110,000 gallons of diesel fuel today off Cape Cod, the Coast Guard said. The ship ran onto rocks in heavy fog and began taking on water Sunday, but the more than 1,060 passengers and crew members were evacuated and damage was at first believed confined to small tears that spilled up to 1,500 gallons of fuel. However, divers late Sunday discovered a 2-foot-wide tear that exposed four of the Bermuda Star's fuel tanks containing 110,000 gallons of diesel, said Coast Guard spokesman Steve Aitkins. ``The potential exists for a medium to high probability of a major oil spill,'' the Coast Guard said in a statement. Cleanup workers manned booms around the 617-foot ship to corral the fuel, and used absorbent material to soak up the spill. Aitkins said that pressure from sea water was keeping most of the diesel in its tanks but that the fuel would have to be unloaded before the vessel could be moved for repairs. The Coast Guard hoped to inspect the vessel at daybreak and use pumps on board to transfer the fuel into the ship's undamaged tanks or into other vessels, Aitkins said. Earlier, he said the Coast Guard would charge Bermuda Star Cruise Line, the ship's owner, with federal pollution charges. The captain, Hans Lewing, and other crew members were given blood and alcohol tests, which are routine after accidents. Results were expected today. The vessel, on a cruise from New York to Nova Scotia, went aground about five miles off Woods Hole while passengers were having breakfast. Tugboats freed it 13 hours later. The passengers and some of the crew were ferried to shore. Flooding through the holes in the hull was under control by midday. Passenger Robert Lewis, Wichita Falls, Texas, said no one on board panicked. ``It was kind of like we bumped into something,'' he said. ``There was a loud grinding noise, but no one seemed to be scared.'' Scot Graham, a Coast Guard marine safety officer in Providence, R.I., said the ship was three hours ahead of schedule and off-course when it ran aground. Fog had cut visibility to about a quarter-mile, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Defendants in Bensonhurst Case to Be Sentenced Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sentencing begins 10 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Community leaders sought to ease racial tensions before today's sentencing of two white men convicted in the mob attack in Bensonhurst that left a black teen-ager dead. Prosecutors said they would seek the maximum penalties for Joseph Fama and Keith Mondello, both 19. The shooting death Aug. 23 of Yusuf Hawkins, 16, raised racial tensions in the city during a mayoral campaign. Hawkins was attacked after he and three friends went to the mostly white Brooklyn neighborhood to look at a used car. Fama, named as the triggerman by his co-defendants, was convicted May 17 of murder, riot and other crimes. He faced up to 32 and two-thirds years to life in prison. Mondello, the mob's alleged organizer, was acquitted a day later of murder and manslaughter but convicted of riot and other offenses. Prosecutors said they would seek consecutive sentences for Mondello, which could keep him in prison for five and one-third to 16 years, and the maximum sentence of 25 years to life for Fama on the murder charge. With the Fama conviction, the city remained calm. But when Mondello's verdict was delivered, crowds of blacks hurled rocks and bottles in Brooklyn, and several white reporters were roughed up. In recent days, the Rev. Al Sharpton _ a flamboyant civil-rights activist who has been accused of rabble-rousing and race-baiting _ played the peacemaker. He canceled a protest over the weekend in Bensonhurst. ``We don't have to like each other, but we have to live with each other,'' Sharpton said. Leaders of the largely Italian-American neighborhood promised to work with the black community to help heal racial divisions. ``Bensonhurst will show the world that people who have been represented as enemies can come together and live the life of the lamb, not the lion,'' said Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, a Brooklyn Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: Saving Supertanker Will Be a Delicate Task
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Using too much water to douse the fire aboard the Mega Borg could sink the oil supertanker, but firefighters using foam to smother the flames today faced another problem, salvage experts say. ``You have to get on that ship to extinguish it,'' said Les Williams, whose Port Arthur, Texas, salvage company has fought nearly two dozen offshore oil fires. ``If the fire's below deck, it's like trying to walk on a hot skillet. You can't do that.'' The fire burned since Saturday aboard the 853-foot Norwegian ship, crippled in the Gulf of Mexico 57 miles southeast of Galveston. It started with an explosion in the engine room on Saturday; five blasts Sunday sent blazing crude oil from the tanker's 38-million-gallon cargo into the sea. ``That's a very hard fire to fight, there in the engine room like that,'' Rudy Teichmann of T&T Marine Salvage Inc. in Galveston said. ``It's all closed up and you can't get to it. ``They can't flood that engine room with water. That could sink the ship. It's a lot different than fighting a forest fire,'' said Teichmann. The Mega Borg already was listing. Its stern dropped 58 feet since the first explosion, indicating either the cargo had shifted or the ship was taking on water, the Coast Guard said. The aft deck was reported just 5 feet above the water today. About 30,000 gallons of foam has been shipped to the scene, the Coast Guard said. But using it entails firefighting at close range. Wiliams said the usual procedure is for two or three firefighters, wearing fire-retardant jumpsuits that are light enough to swim in, to board the tanker. Carrying a 3-inch diameter hose leading to foam pumps aboard a nearby boat, they target the fire's point of origin, he said. The hose, or ``wand,'' can shoot 5,000 gallons of foam per minute. Attempting the job is Smit American Salvage Inc., the U.S. division of a Rotterdam company. Smit has helped fight more than 100 tanker and oil rig fires, including blazes in the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq war, company officials said. Steve Davis, captain of the 180-foot supply boat Tradewind, and his crew of four spent Sunday loading drums of chemical foam on board the boat to fight the Mega Borg fire. ``I would hate to see oil all over these beaches,'' Davis said as specialists from the Netherlands finished bolting high-powered pumps and nozzle connections to the ship's deck. Davis' boat is one of six from Pelican Island near Galveston that were hired to fight the fire. ``God willing and weather permitting _ that's the saying in salvage,'' said Rick Chianelli, salvage foreman for Smit American.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Communists Hold Lead in First Free Elections in 58 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with opposition charging some fraud but its chairman saying he doubts it will challenge results. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The renamed Communists held a commanding lead today in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years, bucking the anti-Communist trend in countries that emerged from the Soviet orbit in the past year. The party, and once Moscow's most loyal follower, appeared likely to become the only ruling party in Eastern Europe to retain power in multiparty elections, according to projections from independent polling organizations. However, opposition leaders charged that Sunday's parliamentary vote had been marred by irregularities and more than 2,000 protesters demonstrated outside Parliament today, shouting ``fraud'' and calling for a general strike. Police cordoned off the building, and the crowd appeared to be growing. The opposition scheduled a mass evening rally for downtown Sofia. Independent projections gave the Socialists, heirs to the long-ruling Communists, about 48 percent of the vote in Sunday's parliamentary vote. The main opposition coalition, the Union of Democratic Forces, had just under 35 percent. Official results were expected later today. There were complaints from opposition officials that the ballot-counting was moving very slowly. But Union chairman Zhelyu Zhelev told reporters that he did not believe the opposition would challenge the elections' validity. ``In the worst case we shall want new elections (in districts) where there have been real flagrant violations,'' he said. The West German polling organization Infas said the opposition won the capital of Sofia, where it was expected to receive about 55 percent of the vote against 38 percent for the Socialists, who called themselves Communist until April. However, the Union lagged behind in the countryside, where analysts had expected the opposition to have a tough time. For many people outside Sofia, radical change is feared and the Socialists represent stability. The Socialists favor introducing economic reforms gradually, avoiding the ``shock therapy'' that has caused steep price rises and widespread unemployment in Poland. The 16-party Union of Democratic Forces favors a swift move to a market economy and restoring private ownership. Its supporters say it offers the best guarantee of democratic change. The Socialists have said they want to govern in a coalition with the opposition in order to get a broad-based consensus for tackling the country's economic problems. Union leaders have ruled out such a coalition. At least 84 percent of the country's 6.4 million eligible voters cast ballots for the 400-seat Grand National Assembly, the Central Election Commission said late Sunday. In all, 3,143 candidates from 38 parties ran for election to the parliament. Half of the seats will be awarded on the basis of proportional representation, the others allocated according to results in 200 districts races. Runoffs are to be held Sunday where no candidate wins a majority. Bulgaria is the fifth Eastern European country to hold free parliamentary elections this year. The Communists suffered resounding defeats in East Germany, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. In Romaia, the National Salvation Front, a coalition dominated by former Communists that took power after the overthrow and execution of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, won multiparty elections. In Bulgaria, reform Communists engineered the nation's drive to democracy, removing long-time hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in November. President Petar Mladenov has won public support for initiating reforms that included a renunciation of the party's monopoly on power. The Bulgarian Communist Party also has deep roots in the country. The party was founded in 1891, predating the Soviet Communist Party. It captured 20 percent of the vote in 1932, the country's last free elections, and has ruled Bulgaria since 1944. Opposition leaders charged that a Socialist victory would stem from the continuing strong influence through patronage of the Communist ``nomenklatura,'' or apparatus. But political observers said the Union lost potential supporters because of poor leadership. The Association for Free and Fair Elections, a Bulgarian monitoring group, said its vote projections gave the Socialists 48.3 percent of the vote against 34.9 percent for the Union and 8.3 percent for the Agrarian Party, formerly a docile ally of the Communists. Infas had similar projections. The only other party projected to win seats was the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, which was receiving about 80 percent of the vote in areas heavily populated by the 1.5 million ethnic Turkish minority, BTA reported. The projections gave the ethnic Turkish group from 5.7 to 8.4 percent of the vote nationwide. Thousands of Bulgarian and foreign observers monitored the voting. There were only scattered reports of irregularities, including allegations of stolen ballot papers and last-minute campaigning banned under election law. Opposition campaign manager Petko Simeonov told a news conference today that the Union believed the elections to have been fair in most places. However, he said he gave election officials a list of 211 cases of alleged violations. Simeonov said conditions for free elections had been secured in most places, but ``there has been strong moral pressure on the electorate, especially in small villages.'' He claimed that after the voting, ``signals of different violations of (election) procedure came like a tidal wave.'' Beforehand, actor and opposition activist Yosif Serchadzhiev, alleging electoral fraud in the village of Pazardzhik during an appearance on live national televison, burst into tears and ran off camera. Heated on-air exchanges and shouting followed. The main task of the new parliament will be to write a new consititution to usher in democratic and economic reforms. The parliament must also deal with a $10 billion foreign debt, growing inflation and shortages of basic consumer items including sugar and cheese.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against most major foreign currencies in calm European trading today. Gold prices were higher. Continued unrest in the Soviet Union and confusion surrounding the impact of German unification were supporting the dollar, traders said. Working against it were fears the West German central bank would intervene if the dollar moved too high. ``A majority of people are now talking about a higher dollar,'' said Gerhard Sunderdiek, a trader at Bank of America in Frankfurt. A trader in Milan, Italy, said the dollar was well bid, ``but still trading without a particular direction.'' He predicted U.S. economic indicators to be released later this week would give the market some direction. The May producer price index is due for release Thursday. May's consumer price index and April trade figures are due out on Friday. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.45 yen to a closing 154.10 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.30 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6959 West German marks, down from 1.6973 _1.4435 Swiss francs, down from 1.4480 _5.7097 French francs, down from 5.7155 _1.9100 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9088 _1,245.50 Italian lire, down from 1,248.50 _1.1687 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1743 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6812, compared with $1.6843 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $354.50 a troy ounce, unchanged from Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $354.70. In Zurich, the bid price was $354.50, up from $354.00 Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.28 to close at a bid $355.75. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.99 a troy ounce, from Friday's $5.02.

DOC.HEAD: West Gets Cool Weather, Midwest Hit by Thunderstorms
DOC.TEXT: Cool weather settled in the West today and scattered thunderstorms threatened the Great Lakes region. Thunderstorms were forecast for portions of the Dakotas, Nebraska, Minnesota, Iowa and the western Great Lakes states. New England, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming and Montana also were in for gusty winds and rain. Skies were cloudy early today in parts of New Mexico, Alaska, Oregon and Washington. Early morning conditions were fair elsewhere. Daytime temperatures in the West were expected to be an average of 8 to 16 degrees below normal. Daytime temperatures in the 60s and 70s were forecast for portions of Washington, Arizona, Oregon and Utah. California's forecast called for fair, dry conditions for most of the week. Warm weather and scattered thunderstorms prevailed Sunday throughout the United States. Strong storms hit the Southeast, the central Plains and parts of Nevada. A late spring storm dumped more than an inch of rain on the Las Vegas Valley, flooding streets and homes, knocking out power and drowning a woman who was trapped in a car swept into a drainage ditch. The Arkansas town of Rogers received more than 1.5 inches of rain in 30 minutes Sunday. Rain also fell in New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Kansas and the Florida peninsula. The nation's high Sunday was 102 degrees in Presidio, Texas.
