The poll said that 79 percent of the public is either very concerned or somewhat concerned about threats to their personal privacy, compared with 77 percent in a 1983 Harris survey and 64 percent in 1978. In 1970, only 34 percent said they were concerned about privacy issues. Thirty percent said they had decided against applying for a job, credit or insurance because they didn't want to provide certain kinds of information about themselves, the survey said. But 78 percent said they would be upset if they couldn't get credit based on their record of paying bills, the survey said. Humphrey Taylor, president of Louis Harris, said the poll sends a warning to private business, adding, ``It would be a serious mistake for business to ignore the high and growing levels of concern that we are reporting today.'' Most Americans are willing to give personal information when they believe it will be used in ways they consider proper, such as employers checking whether a job applicant has a criminal record and credit card companies checking a person's credit history, the poll said. Eighty-three percent of the respondents said employers should be allowed to require drug tests for job applicants. Sixty-nine percent said phone companies should be allowed to offer ``Caller ID,'' which displays the phone number of an incoming call, if customers can ``block'' their number from being shown. The random telephone poll included 2,254 interviews in January and February, and an additional 2,253 interviews in April, with about half of the first group of people being re-interviewed. The margin of error was plus or minus 2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Case of Missing Desk Continues to Baffle
DOC.TEXT: Mystery fans, take heart. There may yet be a solution to the Case of the Missing Desk. For the time being, though, followers of this enduring Boston mystery are going to have to settle for clues that only raise more questions. Did the mayor do it? Which mayor? And whose desk is it anyway? Here's the lowdown: The ornate, hand-carved mahogany desk supposedly belonged to legendary four-term Mayor James Michael Curley, who left office in 1949, but the furniture disappeared when Mayor Kevin White left office in 1984. Now Mayor Raymond Flynn wants it back. And White says he may be able to find it. But he says it wasn't Curley's desk to begin with. Got it? The desk has become something of a cause celebre in Boston, where it has been rumored to be hidden in White's Beacon Hill townhouse, his Cape Cod summer home, with his relatives, in a courthouse basement or in an office building near City Hall. The Suffolk County district attorney's office has investigated and found nothing. A Boston radio state has offered an expense-paid trip to Ireland for its recovery. Still, no desk. In a television interview Sunday, White revived the mystery. When asked him about the desk, he said, ``Gee, I can only blush at that. I don't know, as God is my judge, where the Curley desk is.'' And anyway, he said, the desk was originally his, not Curley's. Curley served four non-consecutive terms between 1914 and 1949. White, who served four consecutive terms from 1968-84, said an aide told him before he left office that ``somebody thinks that's the Curley desk, and Flynn wants it. You'd better leave it. ``And I said, `It isn't the Curley desk. Flynn can't have it. I want it and that's the end of that.' White said he went on vacation and the desk disappeared. ``And now I don't know where it is, but I can find it,'' he said. White said he doesn't know what to do with the desk once he finds it. ``The question is: Do I produce the Curley desk that I know is not the Curley desk and let them believe it? Or, do I refuse out of obstinacy to give them the desk they think is the Curley desk, which I know it isn't?'' But Flynn said he believes White knows where the desk is hidden and that it indeed belonged to Curley. ``It's pretty obvious James Michael Curley had a desk,'' said Flynn. ``There are pictures of him sitting behind it. It's legendary. Prominent people appeared in the mayor's office.''

DOC.HEAD: Co-Founder of Fine Arts Radio Station Dies of Cancer at 62
DOC.TEXT: Rita Jacobs Willens, co-founder of acclaimed fine arts radio station WFMT, has died of lung cancer at age 62. Mrs. Willens died Sunday at her home in suburban Barrington Hills. With her former husband, Bernard Jacobs, Mrs. Willens helped prove that a commercial station shunning pop music could thrive. Founded 40 years ago, the station is known for broadcasting classical music, live concerts, jazz seminars and documentaries by Chicago author Studs Terkel. She joined radio station WOAK-FM in suburban Oak Park and in 1950 married Jacobs, the station's general manager. He changed the station's format from pop to classical and the couple presided over its success under the new call letters. The station grew in stature by syndicating programming, including symphonies and Terkel's interviews, to more than 500 radio stations. ``I heard her playing Woodie Guthrie. That's why I joined,'' Terkel recalled. ``The station was something wholly different, based on the idea that there's a Chicago public, of all sorts of people, who deserved better than what they were getting. ``She had great energy and imagination,'' Terkel said of Mrs. Willens. ``She and Bernie shared a vision that people had better taste than they were given credit for.'' The couple divorced in 1966; the station was sold to WGN Continental Broadcasting Co. two years later. In 1967, she married ad executive David Willens, who died in 1986. Jacobs died in 1975. WGN donated the station to its current owner, the Chicago Educational Television Association. Mrs. Willens maintained ties to WFMT until 1981. She is survived by two sons, two daughters and a sister. A graveside service was scheduled for Monday at Westlawn Cemetery.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Sources Say Mayor Won't Run Again _ But Won't Say So Yet
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 6 grafs for last 5 grafs, Meanwhile, seven, to update with jury pool total now at 58, detail
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry has made a firm decision to abandon his re-election plans but has put off an announcement for several days in an angry reaction to pressure from Jesse Jackson and others, sources close to the mayor said Monday. Barry had planned to make his decision public Monday night in hopes of restarting stalled plea bargain talks as jury selection continued in his drug possession and perjury trial, the sources said. However, a scheduled interview on a local television program was canceled, Barry press spokeswoman Cheryl Crowell said. More meetings with campaign officials are in the planning stages, but the mayor is now expected to announce his decision later this week, one Barry aide said. The embattled mayor met with about a dozen top advisers and fund-raisers Sunday night to discuss his political future. The aide, who attended the meeting and described it only on condition of anonymity, said Barry was clear in telling the group he would not seek a fourth term. ``He was resolute, as firm as he could be,'' said the aide. ``With him, he can always change his mind, but he's pretty far down the road.'' Barry is delaying making the announcement because of pressure from Jackson, from District Delegate Walter Fauntroy _ who is a candidate to succeed Barry as Mayor _ and from others who have urged him publicly to drop out of the race, the sources said. ``There have been some intrusive parties, Jesse and others,'' one source said. ``The man wants to act on his own, without seeming to be pushed around.'' The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Plea discussions, which started more than two weeks ago, broke down last week with U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens insisting that Barry plead guilty to a felony charge and the mayor willing to consider only a misdemeanor plea, sources familiar with the situation have said. The talks have not revolved around Barry's re-election plans, the sources said. Judy Smith, a spokeswoman for Stephens, was not immediately available for comment. A guilty plea to any of the perjury charges probably would result in Barry drawing a prison term under federal sentencing guidelines. In that event, he could not continue to hold office or run for re-election. Sources close to Jackson said he is miffed that the mayor has failed to announce his decision not to seek re-election after telling the civil rights leader first that he would make the announcement Friday and then that he would reveal his plans Monday. Jackson has said publicly that he urged Barry to drop his bid for the mayor's chair and seek a plea agreement in order to spare the city the pain of a drawn-out trial. Jackson also predicted last week that Barry would make the announcement soon. Jackson was traveling and not immediately available to comment. Meanwhile, 10 prospective jurors were added to the jury pool Monday, bringing the total number of potential jurors to 58. Excused from jury duty was a woman who said she knows a Barry bodyguard, James Stays. The woman said she had asked Stays whether the mayor used drugs and Stays told her no. The bodyguard is on the list of witnesses the mayor might call in his defense. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson questioned whether the woman would be able to consider Stays' testimony fairly and impartially given the fact that she said she has known the bodyguard for several years and speaks to him frequently. Another prospective juror, a man, said the Barry case has left an ``impression of sleaze that has rubbed off on everyone.'' Barry spent the day in court and bantered with reporters as he left the courthouse, but did not respond to questions about whether he intended to announce he would not seek re-election.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events involving the Supreme Court's decisions on flag-burning and efforts to reinstate penalties for desecration.

June 21 _ The Supreme Court, in a 5-4 ruling, declares that burning the American flag as a form of political protest is constitutionally protected free speech, saying ``we do not consecrate the flag by punishing its desecration.'' The defendant in the case, Gregory Johnson, had burned the flag at the 1984 Republican Convention in Dallas.
June 22 _ Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., introduces a proposed constitutional amendment ``to protect the dignity of the U.S. flag.'' A flag-burning was reported in Berkeley, Calif. President Bush told a New York audience, ``Flag burning is wrong _ dead wrong.''
June 23 _ The Senate passes legislation to outlaw flag desecration. The sponsor, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., said he was confident the measure was constitutional. House Speaker Thomas Foley says that changing the Constitution should be viewed with caution.
June 26 _ President Bush's spokesman says he supports legislation to restore criminal penalties for flag desecration but hadn't decided whether to back a constitutional amendment to overturn the Supreme Court decision.
June 27 _ Bush calls for a constitutional amendment to bypass the Supreme Court ruling, saying ``I will uphold our precious right to dissent, but burning the flag goes too far.'' The House approves a resolution expressing ``profound concern'' over the court decision.
June 29 _ Bush and congressional Republicans agree on a proposed constitutional amendment. House members hold an all-night speechmaking session on the flag issue in an empty chamber.
July 13 _ Congress opens hearings on the flag-burning issue, with conservatives seeking a constitutional amendment but Democrats backing a change in law instead.
July 27 _ The House Judiciary Committee approves a flag-protection bill over Republican objections that it wouldn't overcome the Supreme Court decision.
Aug. 10 _ The American Bar Association's policy-making body votes to oppose a constitutional amendment to ban flag desecration.
Sept. 12 _ The House votes 380-38 to approve legislation restoring criminal penalties for flag-burning.
Sept. 21 _ The Senate Judiciary Committee approves a proposed flag bill and disapproves a constitutional amendment but sends both to the floor for action.
Oct. 15 _ The Senate approves a flag desecration bill 91-9. Bush says he respects ``the intention'' but still will seek a constitutional amendment.
Oct. 12 _ The House votes final approval for the flag bill, 371-43. The next day, Bush says he'll allow the bill to become law without his signature.
Oct. 19 _ The Senate defeats an anti-flag-burning constitutional amendment, with the 51-48 vote falling 15 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed for passage.
Oct. 28 _ The flag desecration law takes effect, and minutes later a Seattle crowd torches a pile of American flags, chanting ``burn, baby, burn.'' Four people were arrested. Flag burnings occur in other cities in following days, and three people were charged with burning a flag on the U.S. Capitol steps on Oct. 30.

Feb. 21 _ A federal judge in Seattle rules the flag desecration law is unconstitutional.
March 5 _ A federal judge in Washington D.C. rules the law is unconstitutional. The law provides for direct appeal to the Supreme Court.
May 14 _ The Supreme Court hears arguments on the new flag desecration law.
June 11, 1990 _ The Supreme Court, in a 5-4 split identical to that in the 1989 ruling, struck down the new federal law that outlaws burning the American flag, saying the ban ``dilutes the very freedom that makes this emblem so revered.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for 7 p.m. EDT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead; INSERTS new grafs 6-8 with embargoed Salinas remarks, ``Salinas told U.S. ...'' ADDS two new ending grafs with embargoed Salinas comments on impact of pact on U.S. jobs; SUBS 5th graf pvs to CORRECT spelling of Monterrey
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Mexico took a first step Monday toward negotiating a free trade pact that a White House official said could one day lead to a single North American market. President Bush and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari agreed at a private dinner Sunday night to have their trade officials begin preparations for the formal talks, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``The presidents agreed that the greatest possible mutual benefit would derive from an agreement that entails gradual and comprehensive elimination of trade barriers,'' Fitzwater said. He said ``preparatory work'' by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Jaime Puche, Mexico's minister of commerce and industrial development, would be done between now and December, when the two presidents will meet again. That session is tentatively scheduled for Monterrey, Mexico. Salinas told U.S. business leaders that ``the most important immediate result'' of a U.S.-Mexican free-trade agreement ``will be to increase trade and investment flows between both nations.'' ``We need our exports to have stable, secure access to the U.S. market,'' he said in remarks prepared for delivery to the Business Round Table. In exchange, Salinas said, Mexico will provide new markets for U.S. goods and new investment opportunities for American businesses. ``Mexico does not want to be late for the world's appointment with the 21st Century,'' Salinas added. The two countries will seek a pact that will ``improve and expand the flow of goods, services and investment between the United States and Mexico,'' Fitzwater said. He said changes in immigration and emigration laws were not envisioned. The United States signed a free-trade pact with Canada in 1988, under which all tariffs and other trade barriers are being eliminated by the year 2000. In his 1988 campaign, Bush proposed a single North American ``trade zone,'' a unified market of 335 million people without trade barriers. Bush still advocates such an approach and ``it is anticipated that would be an end result'' of a trade agreement with Mexico, Fitzwater said. However, he noted a separate free-trade pact would also have to be struck between Mexico and Canada. Bush called Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on Sunday night to tell him of the developments, Fitzwater said. Mulroney ``was supportive,'' the spokesman added. Bush promised the Canadian leader to ``maintain a liaison and consultations as we go through the process,'' the spokesman said. Such a pact would require congressional approval before formal negotiations could commence. Fitzwater said the administration envisioned sending the same general kind of legislation to Congress that set up the U.S.-Canada talks. That measure spelled out a timetable and required Congress to put the final agreement on a ``fast track'' to keep it from getting bogged down. Even so, negotiations on the U.S.-Canadian pact took nearly four years. Fitzwater said Bush and Salinas see free trade as a ``powerful engine for economic development.'' In addition to eliminating tariffs, Fitzwater said a free-trade agreement would also have as a goal doing away with or ``the fullest possible reduction'' of other barriers to trade. The spokesman cited import quotas, licenses and technical barriers. Salinas, in Washington also met Monday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and members of Congress. He was to meet on Tuesday with Vice President Dan Quayle. Although the United States has pressed for free trade between the two nations, Salinas, a Harvard-educated economist, initially was cool to the idea. However, more recently he has suggested that an economic recovery in Mexico will not be possible without it. His change of heart occurred after Mexican efforts to seek foreign investment from Europe fell far short of expectations. Mexico is the United States' third largest trading partner after Canada and Japan, with two-way trade of $52 billion last year. The United States shipped $24.97 billion worth of exports into Mexico in 1989 and imported $27.19 billion in Mexican goods _ for a U.S. trade deficit with Mexico of $2.2 billion. Winning congressional agreement on an elimination of all trade barriers with Mexico could prove more difficult than getting passage of the Canadian pact. The AFL-CIO has voiced skepticism about such an arrangement, suggesting that a free-trade pact could cost jobs in the United States once tariffs were removed on Mexican products made by low-paid Mexican workers. ``The jobs issue is a difficult one,'' Fitzwater said. ``It's one both sides are aware of. We want an agreement that is beneficial to both sides, both in terms of investment as well as jobs and labor markets.'' Salinas, in his speech, called ``unfounded'' concerns by U.S. labor of job losses. ``To assume that the creation of new jobs in Mexico will be attained at the expense of the American worker is to ignore Mexico's enormous potential as a market for United States exports and the complementarity of our economies,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Second Nuclear Test of Year Planned at Nevada Site
DOC.TEXT: Scientists plan to detonate the second announced underground nuclear weapons test of the year Wednesday at the Nevada Test Site, the Department of Energy said. The test, with a yield of between 20 and 150 kilotons, may be felt in highrise buildings as far away as Las Vegas, 85 miles from the blast site, the DOE said. Workers were warned not to be in precarious positions at the time of detonation. Barring weather problems or technical difficulties, the DOE said the weapon will be detonated at 9 a.m., some 2,200 feet beneath the surface of Pahute Mesa. The test is the first since March 10 and only the second of the year at the nation's nuclear proving grounds. Last year, 12 nuclear weapons were exploded underground at the desert site. In recent years, the DOE has tested an average of about one nuclear weapon a month. The test will be the 701st since testing began at the site in 1951.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Wants More Regulations For Cosmetics
DOC.TEXT: More effective and consistent regulation is needed to ensure the safety of cosmetics that do more than cleanse and beautify, a House subcommittee chairman said Monday. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation, said too many products that meet the definitions for both cosmetics and drugs slip through regulatory cracks in current law. This group of ``cosmeceuticals'' _ including anti-wrinkle and anti-aging creams, moisturizers, astringents and skin firmers _ are regulated on the basis of marketing claims. Wyden released a Congressional Research Service report that he said shows ``two products with exactly the same ingredients can fall under entirely different regulations based on the fancy wording of smart advertisers.'' Current law defines a cosmetic as something that is used to clean and beautify. A drug, under the law, is something used to diagnose, cure, treat, prevent disease or alter the structure or function of the body. While drugs must undergo safety and effectiveness testing before they can be marketed, cosmetics ``are the least regulated articles under the federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act,'' the report said. In deciding whether a product is a cosmetic or a drug, the FDA looks at ``intended use,'' as reflected in the manufacturer's claims for the product, the report said. For example, a skin lotion that claims to physiologically get rid of wrinkles is classified as a drug and must be safety tested. However, if the same lotion claimed only to beautify the skin, it would be considered a cosmetic and free of regulation. If it claims to be a sun screen, it is a drug. Wyden said the ambiguity in the current law, which dates to 1938, needs to be corrected to ensure that all cosmetics are safe. The report offered several legislative options to clarify the classification of drugs and cosmetics. Wyden will use it to help draft legislation providing for minimal regulation of the $18 billion a year cosmetics industry. Provisions are expected to include registration of manufacturers and requirements that they submit injury and testing reports to the Food and Drug Administration, a spokeswoman for the congressman said. FDA officials were reviewing the report.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, Calm Reigns in Eastern Coal Fields
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Other states ...,' to ADD Indiana to list of states affected.
DOC.TEXT: One year after a wildcat miners strike erupted in the Appalachian coal fields, calm reigns above and below ground. Miners angry about stalled settlement talks between The Pittston Co. and workers taking part in a sanctioned strike began walking off the job a year ago Tuesday. The wildcat strike lasted about six weeks and idled 46,000 miners. ``It's the closest I've come to seeing what they call spontaneous uprisings in Poland or Czechoslovakia,'' said UMW spokesman John Duray in Washington, D.C. ``One day everything's peaceful and the next day everything starts.'' Within 10 days, the sympathy strike that began in southern West Virginia had spread to 10 states. United Mine Workers officials ultimately ordered a cooling-off period and miners returned to work. Other states affected were Indiana, Illinois, Pennsylvania, Alabama, Ohio, Kentucky, Virginia, Missouri and Tennessee. Coal company officials are reluctant to talk about the wildcat strike, but Duray said there is one obvious lesson for both management and labor. ``Considering the nature of these walkouts, I'd say solidarity is alive and well in the (United) Mine Workers,'' Duray said. The Pittston strike, which idled about 1,700 union miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky, began April 5, 1989, and was settled on New Year's Day. The miners went back to work in February. Most of the legal disputes stemming from the Pittston strike have been settled, but the same can't be said about the lawsuits and National Labor Relations Board complaints filed because of the wildcat strike. Union officials said they did not authorize the wildcat action, but have reached a tentative settlement with the NLRB on hundreds of coal company complaints alleging that the union organized the walkouts in a bid to pressure Pittston. The union says it won't release details of the settlement until it is completed. Dozens of lawsuits filed by coal companies seeking to recover income lost because of the wildcat strike are pending. The walkout was the first major wildcat strike by miners since the late 1970s, when such actions could be counted on to bring production to a halt, often because of issues outside the coal companies' control. ``You had in West Virginia in the 1970s strikes over the textbooks used in the schools, strikes over gasoline lines, all kinds of (things) happened,'' Duray said. In one incident, miners at a western Pennsylvania mine walked off the job for two days because of a report that a worm had been found in a water cooler. Union president Rich Trumka has softened some of the union's oldtime militancy, favoring selective strikes over wildcat walkouts and persuading members to abandon their once-ironclad policy of ``no contract, no work.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says ANC Deserves Sole Credit for Ongoing Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela told thousands of cheering supporters Monday that the African National Congress, not the South African government, deserves sole credit for initiating peace talks. He also urged continued pressure for economic sanctions as long as apartheid exists in South Africa. ``Sanctions were introduced at the insistence of the African National Congress for the purpose of removing apartheid in all its forms,'' Mandela said. ``The idea was to ensure all people of South Africa _ black and white _ are able to determine their own affairs ... to ensure a non-racial, democratic and united South Africa. We are still very far from that.'' Mandela, deputy leader of the ANC, spoke to about 4,000 people outside the headquarters of the opposition West German Social Democratic Party, which invited him to visit. He stopped in the West German capital on a tour of Europe and North America to argue against lifting of sanctions against South Africa. Britain and some other countries have said President F.W. de Klerk should be rewarded for his steps toward ending South Africa's racial strife, including freeing Mandela after 28 years in jail; legalizing the black nationalist movement; and lifting the state of emergency in three of the four provinces. Mandela, 71, said de Klerk should be admired for having the courage to say the government's previous position was wrong, but that it was ANC campaigning and economic sanctions that finally brought the government to peace talks. ``The credit for the discussions that are now going on in South Africa in the search of peace comes to the African National Congress and the African National Congress alone,'' the black leader said. Mandela criticized countries that may be considering lifting sanctions, saying they were not thinking of South Africa as a whole, but only of the white minority. ``One of the most dangerous tendencies in the world is people who always think in terms of their flesh and blood when they're dealing with problems. Those who call for the lifting of sanctions are making precisely that mistake,'' Mandela said. He said the reality in South Africa was that ``apartheid was still in place.'' ``There are blacks who have no rights. There are whites who enjoy all the basic human rights.'' The European Economic Community, to which West Germany belongs, agreed on non-binding measures against South Africa in 1986, banning imports of iron, steel and gold coins and banning new investments in South Africa. Britain unilaterally lifted its ban on new investments in South Africa in February. The sanctions issue is expected to come up at a meeting next week in Luxembourg of the 12 EEC foreign ministers. Mandela and his wife, Winnie, arrived in Bonn Sunday night. On Tuesday, Mandela will meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. At a dinner Monday for Mandela, former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt called Mandela ``the truly legitimate spokesman for the majority of South Africa's population.'' But he noted: ``Nelson Mandela, viewed by many of us as the future South African president, in his own land still has no voting right. He cannot freely choose his apartment. Not all public facilities are available to him. ``When he has the same rights as President de Klerk, then the time will have come to introduce a new era of economic cooperation.''

DOC.HEAD: Employer Reported in Ecuardorean Jungle To Negotiate American's Release
DOC.TEXT: A ransom deadline set by leftist guerrillas threatening to kill their American hostage passed Monday, and the man's employer was said to have gone into the jungle to meet with the kidnappers. Friends and family of kidnapped engineer Scott Heimdal, 27, of Peoria, Ill., have collected the $60,000 the guerrillas are demanding, but it was not immediately known if the payment would be made. Jeffrey Fino, local manager of the Iminco mining company, flew to an airstrip near the San Miguel River, company sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The river runs along Ecuador's border with Colombia, 100 miles northeast of Quito. The sources did not confirm that Fino was carrying the $60,000. Heimdal's family in Peoria collected the money from friends and well-wishers and the cash was transferred to a Quito bank over the weekend. Heimdal's parents plan to come to this Andean nation Wednesday or Thursday. Volunteers in Peoria have been raising money to pay for their flight. Heimdal was kidnapped on April 28 by members of the Popular Liberation Army, a small guerrilla group that operates in southern Colombia. He was traveling along the Bermeja River in a boat that was ambushed six miles from the Colombian border. The skipper was killed and one passenger wounded in the attack. A passenger abducted with Heimdal and later released said the engineer was taken across the border into Colombia. The rebels have released at least two photographs of Heimdal in captivity. In his latest letter, dated May 14, Heimdal said the guerrillas moved him every day. State Department officials in Washington said the guerrillas kidnapped two other Americans in the past. One died of a heart attack and the other was released upon payment of an unspecified amount of money, they said. Officials of the Ecuadorean government and the U.S. Embassy have not commented on the progress of negotiations. A government source, speaking on condition of not being identified, said low-profile negotiations are most likely to succeed. The source said a Spanish bull salesman kidnapped last month in Quito by a different band of Colombian guerrillas was released unharmed upon payment of $1 million. Lack of publicity aided in the negotiations, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush in First-Ever White House Meeting With East German Leader
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with de Maiziere and White House quotes; picks up 6th graf pvs, The president
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with an East German prime minister for the first time Monday as the White House cited ``considerable progress'' toward persuading Moscow to accept a united Germany in NATO. But Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said later that he emphasized to Bush the nature of NATO must be ``significantly changed'' in order to meet the Soviet Union's security concerns. ``I made clear to him what psychological difficulties this would signify,'' de Maiziere told German reporters as he visited the Lincoln Memorial after his Oval Office meeting at the White House. He added he believes NATO membership for a united Germany ``is only thinkable'' if a treaty clearly defines the status of Soviet troops now stationed in East Germany. The East German prime minister said it remains open whether such a treaty should be between NATO and the Warsaw Pact or between a united Germany and the Soviet Union. De Maiziere said Bush insisted such a question would have to be resolved by the countries negotiating the unification of East and West Germany. The White House said in a statement that Bush and de Maiziere agreed a united Germany ``should enjoy full sovereignty from the time of its unification, with no discriminatory constraints on its sovereignty, and that Germany should be free to choose its own alliance arrangements.'' The two leaders met in the Oval office after posing for photographs on the steps overlooking the White House Rose Garden. They held expanded talks in the Cabinet Room and lunched in the family quarters of the White House. ``He was so emotional about it. He had never been here,'' Bush told White House visitors later, describing his meeting with de Maiziere as ``wonderful.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush stressed his belief that a united Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is essential for European security and will pose no threat to the Soviet Union. The president also said negotiations will result in an end to the rights held in the two Germanys by the four main victors of World War II _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said he is unwilling to accept continued German membership in NATO on grounds it is a U.S.-led, anti-Soviet military alliance. He wants a united Germany to hold membership in the Warsaw Pact as well as NATO. But Fitzwater said Gorbachev's summit meeting with Bush early this month, and later assurances offered by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, may be helping change Gorbachev's mind. ``I think we feel considerable progress has been made,'' Fitzwater said. ``It's clear that this is going to be a gradual process ... I can't report any conclusion to the matter, but we do feel progress is going to be made,'' he said. De Maiziere holds the distinction of being the first _ and probably the last _ prime minister of the German Democratic Republic to be invited to the White House, The two German states are ready to form a monetary union next month on a basis that will provide large subsidies from prosperous West Germany for the economically struggling and cash-poor East. A German national election could be held as early as next January to end the division imposed after the World War II defeat of Nazi Germany. Bush, who had dinner Friday night with visiting West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, anticipated de Maiziere's visit as ``just one more step that demonstrates the magnificent changes that have taken place over the past year and a half.'' De Maiziere, 50, is chairman of the East German Christian Democratic Union. He was responsible for church affairs in the government of Hans Modrow, the last communist leader. In addition to meeting with Bush and Baker, de Maiziere planned to lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, meet the president of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council and deliver a lecture at Georgetown University's Foreign Service School. On Tuesday he will meet with senators and members of the House and speak at the National Press Club. He will then return to New York for a meeting with U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar before returning to East Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Parliament Approves Right-Wing Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with the conservative nature of government, new quote. Picks up 9th graf `The angry' with editing to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL3,4
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir won narrow parliamentary approval Monday for one of the most right-wing governments in Israel's 42-year history, gaining 62 votes in the 120-seat Knesset. In presenting his 19-member Cabinet, Shamir pledged to seek peace but promised expanded Jewish settlments _ a pledge likely to raise tensions with Washington and the Arabs. It is the first government fully in control of the right-wing Likud bloc since 1984. It takes over at a time of new crisis in the Mideast, with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein issuing threats against Israel and Palestinians asking for escalation of the insurrection in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Monday's vote came after a six-hour debate. Liberal lawmakers accused Likud of using bribery to forge the coalition with nine small far-right and religious parties. The rival Labor Party said the new government cannot bring peace. Shamir called the criticisms ``pitiful'' and asked Israelis to make their No. 1 task the absorption of thousands of Soviet Jewish immigrants. ``This is the mission that will be the focus of government activity and after it all the rest _ strengthening peace, advancing toward peace, economy and social problems,'' he told reporters after the balloting. The vote was 62 for the government, 57 against with one abstention. It installed Israel's 24th government since the state's founding on May 15, 1948. Shamir, 74, is serving as premier for the fourth time. He first got the job in 1983 when Likud founder Menachem Begin stepped down. That right-wing government fell later that year, but Shamir stayed in power until the 1984 elections. Since then, close elections have forced Likud and the left-of-center Labor Party into power-sharing coalitions. The political bickering that accompanied the new government's birth raised questions about whether the coalition of diverse factions could survive until the 1992 scheduled election. Shamir and his Likud allies spent the day warding off threats of defection, and it was uncertain if the Knesset, or parliament, would back the new government until the vote was cast. The ultra-Orthodox Shas Party threatened to pull out over a police investigation of alleged fraud by one of its leaders, and four parliament members warned they would abstain or vote no because they did not get ministerial positions. David Levy, a leading Likud figure and the foreign minister, walked out of a meeting with Shamir because he was only one of two deputy premiers and not Shamir's undisputed successor. But in the end all the defection threats proved empty as Shamir got the 62 votes he forecast when he announced the government last Friday. Demonstrators gathered outside the Knesset to demand political reform, shouting slogans about concessions made to bring ultra-Orthodox parties into the govermennt. Amnon Rubinstein of the liberal Shinui Party said the bargaining amounted to bribery by offering jobs to defectors from Labor. Former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Labor compared the new Cabinet to Begin's right-wing government elected in 1981 that started the Lebanon war. ``This is a narrow government, narrow in its shoulders and horizons, a government that cannot answer the great challenges and decrease the great dangers,'' he said. Shamir pledged he would continue to seek dialogue with Palestinians and a deeper involvement of Egypt in peace efforts. But he said ``the Arab hatred toward us has not expired. ... The problem is the rejection of the very existence of Israel.'' As he spoke of his government's obligation to seek peace, Shamir was interrupted by jeering from an Israeli Arab Knesset member, Abdul Wahab Daroushe. He shouted back at Daroushe, ``Shut up and let me speak!'' Another Arab parliament member, Tewfik Toubi, said it was ``a black day'' because Shamir's government relied for support on a two-member faction called Moledat, or Homeland, which seeks to expel all Arabs from Israel-held territory. Shamir also got into shouting with Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, who blamed the prime minister for blocking peace moves and said his new government was dangerous for Israel. ``The government proposed today is a shaky one, built on many legs of clay,'' Peres said. ``Its composition, its guidelines are not bringing peace. It has no ability to change, no joy of hope. It is a sad government for its members and a sorrowful government for Israel.'' Shamir's last government, an uneasy alliance between Likud and Labor, collapsed March 15 over Labor's demands that Israel accept a U.S. proposal for opening peace talks with Palestinians. The policy guidelines of Shamir's new government reject talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization and the founding of a Palestinian state, and he made clear he had no intention of giving up the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians hope to create their state. The PLO-backed leaders of the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising gave their views of Shamir's government in a leaflet that called the new coalition a ``terrorist government'' and urged escalating the revolt against occupation. Shamir continued to hint at a ``greater Israel'' _ including the occupied territories _ although such statements have strained relations with the United States. Before agreeing to provide Israel with $400 million in loan guarantees to help settle a flood of Soviet Jewish immigrants, the United States has asked for assurances they will not be moved to occupied land. U.S. policy oppposes all settlements as obstacles to peace. But Shamir has named former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon _ an outspoken advocate of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories _ as housing minister and head of a Cabinet committee on the Soviet immigration.

DOC.HEAD: British Hostage in Lebanon Has 76th Birthday, Fate Unknown
DOC.TEXT: Monday marked the 76th birthday of British pilot Jack Mann _ missing for 13 months now in Lebanon _ and his wife lamented the ``dead silence'' surrounding his fate. ``I am not very bright today. There's so little to say,'' said Sunnie Mann, who spent her husband's birthday in their modest apartment in a seaside residential district of Moslem west Beirut. ``I don't know how he is or how he is surviving. I am doing nothing today. I haven't gone out. I don't have the courage.'' She told The Associated Press she hoped her husband could find the courage to get through his ordeal. Mann was shot down six times by Nazi forces as a Royal Air Force pilot in World War II. Mrs. Mann said previously her husband managed to elude capture after his plane was hit because he would have ``abhorred'' being a captive _ ``He once flew his burning plane all the way from Germany to make a forced landing in England. He had severe burns on nearly nearly 80 percent of his body.'' ``He is a very brave man. I hope somehow he's surviving, but it has just been a dead silence, a dead end, a blank wall,'' Mrs. Mann said. ``I haven't heard anything. The embassy doesn't know anything. I haven't anything to pin any hopes on _ only that he's a natural survivor and I hope he's all right.'' Mann lived with his wife for 40 years in west Beirut. He vanished on May 12, 1989, after setting out from home in his car for the British Bank of the Middle East in Beirut's Syrian-policed Moslem sector. A group calling itself Cells of Armed Struggle sent a statement to a Western news agency the next day saying it had seized a a British captive, without identifying him. The British Foreign Office said that statement was the only indication it had that Mann had been kidnapped. The captors released no other communique about him and none of the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem extremists holding most of the 15 other Western hostages in Lebanon made any claim about Mann. Mann came to Beirut after World War II and worked as a pilot for Middle East Airlines, Lebanon's national carrier, for about 30 years. He retired in the late 1970s and worked as a bartender in a west Beirut pub. His wife ran a horse-training club in south Beirut that was closed after Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Mann is one of four Britons held in Lebanon. The others are Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, journalist John McCarthy and educator Brian Keenan. Six Americans are missing in Lebanon. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the AP, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Five other Westerners are also missing. Shiite fundamentalist leader Hussein Musawi said on May 29 that some British hostages would be released if Britain deported Indian-born Salman Rushdie, a naturalized Briton and author of the novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Iran's late revolutionary patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, said Rushdie blasphemed Islam in the novel and placed Rushdie under a death order in February 1989. A Foreign Office spokesman in London, who by custom spoke on condition of anonymity, reiterated that Britain would take no action against Rushdie. He said the novel ``is a matter between Rushdie and his publisher.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Leaders Fear Government Will Cause Bloodshed
With AM-Israel-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian leaders warned Monday that Israel's new right-wing government will be more prone to violence, and one predicted it will ``sink Israelis and Palestinians in a sea of blood.'' In the occupied West Bank Monday, Israeli troops stormed the hideout of a suspected Palestinian hit squad in Nablus, killing one Arab and wounding three, the army said. Another 17 were caught. Also Monday, underground leaders of the Palestinian uprising urged activists to respond to the new rightist government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir by stepping up attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers in the occupied lands. In a leaflet, the pro-PLO underground leaders urged Palestinians to ``escalate the struggle and burn the ground under the feet of the occupation army and the settlers.'' The harsh reaction came as Parliament approved Shamir's government, which has vowed to crush the 30-month-old rebellion and also expand Jewish settlement in the occupied lands. Shamir has also rejected U.S. proposals for a preliminary dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians in Cairo. The PLO and prominent Palestinians in the occupied lands support such an idea. ``This government is an obstacle to the peace process,'' Saeed Kenaan, a pro-PLO businessman in Nablus, said in a telephone interview Monday. ``Therefore a catastrophe will take place in the region, and I hold the Israeli government and the U.S. government responsible for all the repercussions that will arise,'' he said. Faisal Husseini, a prominent PLO leader who has been mentioned as a potential peace negotiator, agreed. ``This is a government of war, and I think the decisions of such a government will be decisions of war,'' Husseini said. Palestinians warned that violence would escalate if Shamir made good on his threats to crack down on the uprising. ``This government will sink Palestinians and Israelis into a sea of blood,'' said Saeb Erakat, a pro-PLO professor and journalist. An army official said the Palestinians targeted in the Nablus raid were involved in killing several suspected Arab collaborators and firing on Israeli soldiers. The group was hiding in a two-level structure in Nablus' crowded market area, the official said. Troops broke in from the front and back, killing one Arab and wounding three, he said. A home-made weapon and a pistol were seized. Among the detainees were eight wanted men, the army official said. He insisted on anonymity. Arab reporters identified the slain Palestinian as 19-year-old Jamal Akliek, 19, and said he was shot in the head and the hand. They said Akliek was an activist in the Fatah faction of PLO leader Yasser Arafat and was part of a squad known locally as the ``general security group.'' The death raised to 717 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli troops and civilians since the start of the uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in December 1987. Forty-five Israelis have also died.

DOC.HEAD: Stormy Monday
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell on much of the country Monday, including powerful thunderstorms that doused part of Minnesota. The morning storms dumped about 3 inches of rain on south-central Minnesota. Showers and thunderstorms fell during the afternoon from eastern South Dakota to southern and central Minnesota, western Wisconsin, northeast Iowa and southern and central Florida. Showers also extended from western New York state to much of New England, over the Texas coast and from south-central Montana to Wyoming and northern Utah. Scattered rain fell on northwest Montana, the Idaho Panhandle and California's southern coast. Severe thunderstorm watches were posted for western South Dakota and central and southern Florida. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included an inch at Rochester and Minneapolis-St. Paul. Warnings for winds gusting to more than 60 mph were issued for the northern Front Range of the Montana Rockies. Local wind advisories were in effect in parts of the Plains states and the upper Mississippi valley. Temperatures were unseasonably high across the western portion of the Dakotas and the central Plains. At 2 p.m. CDT, Mitchell, S.D., at 90 degrees, was as warm as Del Rio and Houston, Texas. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 44 degrees at Mullen, Idaho, to 95 degrees at Beeville, Texas; Melbourne, Fla., and Waco, Texas. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Monday was 26 degrees at McCall, Idaho, and Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Governor, Sheriff Defend Rap Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez on Monday defended the arrests on obscenity charges of rap musicians and a store owner who sold their records, calling 2 Live Crew's music ``audio pornography.'' But entertainment industry lawyers warned the crackdown could lead to limits nationwide on constitutionally protected free expression, and predicted that a federal judge's ruling that the group's album ``As Nasty As They Want To Be'' contained obscene material would be overturned. In an apparent effort to calm tensions, the Broward County Sheriff's Office and 2 Live Crew arranged Monday to serve a court appearance notice through the group's attorney instead of directly on band member Mark Ross, sought on misdemeanor obscenity charges. The charges arose from a concert early Sunday at which the group performed the banned material. Band leader Luther Campbell and member Christopher Wongwon were arrested shortly after the concert and released on $100 bond each. A fourth member initially was sought but investigators dropped that warrant after deciding they had insufficient evidence to charge him, said Sheriff Nick Navarro. Martinez, who has publicly attacked 2 Live Crew during his campaign for re-election, applauded the crackdown but insisted he did not order it. ``Communities have the right to set a standard. I think this is a form of audio pornography,'' Martinez said. ``A lot of the music is geared to the abuse of women.'' He dismissed arguments that the arrests were politically motivated and possibly violated the First Amendment, noting that U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez had upheld the constitutionality of Broward's ban on obscenity in ruling last week that the album contained obscene and illegal material. The group's attorney, Bruce Rogow, said he filed an appeal to Gonzalez's decision Monday with the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. ``There is a violation of the law,'' the governor said in defending the arrests. ``I don't think there ought to be any consideration because you happen to be well known and happen to earn a lot of money.'' Gonzalez' ruling led to Friday's arrest of a Broward County record store owner after he sold record and tape versions of the album to an undercover agent. Navarro denied he had ordered the musicians arrested because of obscenities directed toward him by Campbell and the crowd at Sunday's concert. ``I take no offense to any of that,'' he said. ``Let 'em go for it.'' Entertainment attorneys said the crackdown would most intimidate large record companies with connections to government-regulated broadcast media, making them think twice before signing or promoting certain artists. ``They have no choice,'' said Peter Thall, whose New York firm represents Foreigner and other music groups. ``This kind of incident generates fear in any company that has to go before licensing agencies.'' Thall also said the arrests smacked of racism. Jay Topkis, a New York attorney who successfully beat efforts to ban D.H. Lawrence's erotic book ``Lady Chatterley's Lover'' 25 years ago, said the 2 Live Crew ban seemed to be part of an increasing effort nationwide to restrict free speech. He cited recent controversy over exhibits of explicit photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. ``Some people are making it their business to try to suppress ideas,'' Topkis said. ``The idea that judges and juries are going to be deciding that rock compositions are obscene seems to me to be an invitation to national muzzling.''

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze and Genscher Discuss German Unification
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet and West German foreign ministers met Monday and said they made progress in discussions on the reunification of Germany and its military future, the Tass news agency said. The talks between Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and his West German counterpart, Hans-Deitrich Genscher, came a week after the superpower summit in Washington. At the summit between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, the Soviet leader objected to a U.S. proposal that a unified Germany join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Shevardnadze and Genscher said at a news conference after their seven hours of talks they made progress toward finding solutions to the security aspects of German reunification. They did not elaborate. The ministers said they agreed to meet again in June. The talks were held in Brest, near the Soviet Union's western border with Poland. In a report from Bonn, Tass said Genscher emphasized a united Germany would recognize the current Polish border and renounce any previous territorial claims to European countries. In Bonn, the West German Foreign Ministry said the ministers also planned to visit the grave of Shevardnadze's brother, a Soviet soldier who died in Brest during World War II. In visits to Canada and the United States, Gorbachev reminded leaders that 27 million Soviets died in the two world wars with Germany. Brest was previously known as Brest-Litovsk. In 1918, toward the end of World War I, the Brest-Litvosk peace treaties were signed there between the central European powers and the Ukraine and Soviet Russia. An independent Ukraine was recognized in one treaty. In the second, Russia acknowledged Ukrainian independence and also lost its Polish and Baltic possessions.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: Labor Leader Regarded as Opportunist
With AM-Israel-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: David Levy, Israel's new foreign minister, worked his way from a ditchdigger to one of the highest-ranking posts ever held by a North African immigrant. A fiery orator, the Moroccan-born Levy, 52, began his political career in the ranks of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc as a labor union boss championing the causes of the disadvantaged. He advanced quickly in the party and is regarded by some as a political opportunist who might compromise ideology in his drive to succeed Shamir as prime minister. Although his appointment is welcomed as a confirmation of the integration Israel's founding fathers espoused, Levy has little experience in foreign policy. Most criticized is Levy's scant knowledge of English, which could hamper communication with the United States on which Israel relies for political support and about $3 billion in annual aid. But unlike most of his predecessors, Levy is fluent in Arabic. Levy has a reputation as a hard-liner, and was one of the party rebels who forced Shamir to accept crippling conditions to his initiative to hold elections in the occupied territories. But insiders suggest Levy's hard-line had less to do with ideology than with his desire to oust the Polish-born Shamir as Likud leader. In 1982, he led opposition within the Likud government to Israel's protracted, three-year war in Lebanon and many of the military moves of his party rival, Ariel Sharon, who as defense minister was the architect of the Lebanon war. At a news conference this week, Levy said his first task as foreign minister would be ``to prevent deterioration and to improve'' Israel's strained ties with the United States. Levy's early years were immersed in the poverty that was typical of many of the 600,000 Jews from Arab lands, or Sephardim, who settled in Israel in the 1950s and '60s. The immigrants and their offspring now comprise more than 60 percent of Israel's 4.5 million citizens and constitute a disproportionately large number of the nation's poor. In his biography, Levy is quoted throughout as being consumed with anger and resentment toward the Israeli establishment because of the poverty and neglect he experienced in Beit Shean, a northern town where he lived after immigrating at age 20 in 1957. For Israel's first 30 years, Israel was governed by the center-left Labor Party, which was dominated by European Jews, or Ashkenazim. ``Why do they take people who come with good will and a lot of love for the land of Israel and grind it into sand?'' biographer Aryeh Avinery quotes Levy as saying. After spending some time unemployed Levy found work as a ditchdigger and construction worker. He was first elected to the Knesset, or parliament, at age 32 in 1969. He won his first Cabinet seat, as immigration minister, in 1977 and has served as housing minister since 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Lincoln Assassination Display Reopens
LaserPhoto WX25
DOC.TEXT: A newly renovated museum displaying more than 400 historical objects relating to Abraham Lincoln's assassination was dedicated Monday at Ford's Th= BOSTON (AP) _ Cleanup crews watched anxiously Monday as choppy seas and stiff winds delayed efforts to unload thousands of gallons of fuel that threatened to spill from the torn hull of the cruise ship Bermuda Star. The 617-foot vessel was freed Sunday night from a rocky ledge off Cape Cod, almost 13 hours after it strayed too close to shore and ran aground in dense fog. Divers found a 90-by-2-foot tear on the ship's bottom after it dropped anchor about 3 miles from the ledge in Buzzard's Bay. The rip exposed four tanks holding more than 110,000 gallons of fuel oil, the Coast Guard said. About 1,500 gallons of fuel leaked before a containment boom was put around the ship, and the tear left the potential for more oil to spill, the Coast Guard said. Up to 1,000 gallons of fuel washed ashore at Naushon Island in Buzzards Bay on Monday, Coast Guard Cmdr. Larry Doyle told an afternoon news conference in Providence, R.I. The oil splashed the largely unpopulated island with a gooey swath up to 4 feet wide along a five-mile stretch of shoreline, Doyle said. Another 100,000 gallons of what Doyle described as ``thick, heavy, dense oil'' may leak into the sea. ``It has the potential to be a medium spill,'' Doyle said. Doyle said the Coast Guard believed it was more prudent to wait for the weather to clear than to risk the safety of the repair crews. ``I'm not in any rush to hurry through that,'' he said. ``The vessel is stable, it's safe.'' Cleanup of Naushon Island, which lies off the tip of Woods Hole west of the Cape Cod Canal entrance, was expected to begin Tuesday morning, Doyle said. Water pressing against the ship kept the oil inside while anchored, the Coast Guard said. Plans to tow the ship to a dry dock in New York had to be scrapped until the holes could be patched and the fuel unloaded. ``If you moved the ship now the inertia of the sea would take away the balancing effect we have, and it would suck the oil right out of the tear in the ship,'' said Steve Aitkins, a Coast Guard spokesman in Boston. But rain and fog, coupled with winds of 15 to 30 mph and 2-to-4-foot waves, threatened efforts to skim off the spilled fuel and unload the rest. ``It's kind of a Catch-22. The weather can help you as much as it can hinder you,'' said Randy Krahn, a Coast Guard petty officer in Providence, R.I. ``The rain can help break up the oil, but too much makes the clean-up harder.'' Forecasters predicted the weather would get worse before it got better, possibly on Tuesday morning. Aitkins said the Coast Guard's Atlantic Area Strike Team in Mobile, Ala., has been notified to be ready to move if the oil starts to leak and local cleanup crews could not contain it. The vessel, on a cruise from New York to Nova Scotia, went aground in fog Sunday morning. The more than 1,060 passengers and some crew members were ferried to New Bedford in the evening and taken by bus to hotels in Boston. ``There was a sudden stop and then a metallic noise, then immediately there was an oily smell. We went out on deck and we could see the oil coming out on the water,'' said passenger Paul Kelly of Columbia, S.C. Tests for drugs and alcohol were performed on key members of the crew, but the results were not immediately available, the Coast Guard said. David Roddy, senior vice president of Bermuda Star Line Cruises in Teaneck, N.J., described the ship's captain, Hans Lewing, as ``an excellent, popular captain'' with 20 years of shipping experience. Lewing had been with the company for three years and had a good record, Roddy said. Passengers who had their seven-day excursion abruptly ended would be offered another week or 10-day cruise or a refund, Roddy said. The company also would pay their airfare to return home from Boston, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Central Asia Death Toll at 116 in Week of Unrest
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Flags flew at half-staff and festivities were canceled Monday in the Soviet Republic of Kirghizia to mourn the 116 people killed in a week of ethnic clashes in Central Asia, the Tass news agency reported. The official news agency and Soviet television said the situation in Central Asia had calmed following clashes between Uzbeks and Kirghiz that broke out after a land dispute. ``A trend toward the stabilization of the situation in the republic's southern region has become apparent,'' Tass said, quoting the republic's Interior Ministry. In Osh, a city near Kirghizia's border with Uzbekistan, shops reopened and public transport was returning to normal, Tass said. The news agency said 116 people died, 468 were wounded and at least 500 acts of arson were committed in the week of violence. In memory of the dead, Tass said, ``flags are flying at half-mast and all recreational and entertainment activities have been suspended.'' Kirghizia's capital of Frunze was calm Monday as television and radio broadcast somber music in memory of the dead, said Albert Bogdanov, a journalist with the Kirtag news agency. On Sunday, students trying to organize rallies in Frunze's main square were turned back by Interior Ministry troops and police, said Ivan Pavlov, a party official in the capital. Rallies in Frunze last week turned into demonstrations against the republic's leaders with thousands of students demanding their resignations and calling on residents to go to Osh and join the battle against the Uzbeks. Officials from the Communist Party and the government visited student and worker dormitories Sunday morning to talk them out of holding rallies, Pavlov said. Armored personnel carriers Monday continued to patrol the main streets of Frunze in districts where trouble had broken out earlier, Bogdanov said in a telephone interview. The bloodshed was the latest ethnic violence to trouble the government of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Nationalities in various republics have used the looser atmosphere under Gorbachev's reform initiatives to vent their frustrations over political and economic woes. The violence started when Uzbeks, who make up one-third of the population, discovered that Kirghiz were being given land for housing, which is critically short in the densely populated and poor regions of Central Asia. The fighting spread to districts around Osh, and thousands of troops were sent in to reinforce the local police. Soviet troops sealed off the border to prevent thousands of Uzbeks from crossing into Kirghizia to join the battle.

DOC.HEAD: Baptist Factions Threaten To Back Away From Chruch if Rivals Win
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of a critical vote among Southern Baptist leaders, moderates and fundamentalists both threatened to back away from the deeply divided church if they lose. ``To say this is an important convention is an understatement,'' said the Rev. Daniel Vestal, the moderate standard-bearer for the church's presidency. ``It's a crucial convention.'' The voting scheduled for Tuesday afternoon will likely decide the future of the nation's largest denomination, which has 14.9 million members. The outcome of the so-called ``battle of New Orleans'' is up in the air, insiders said Monday. ``It's going to be close,'' said the Rev. Paige Patterson of Dallas, a chief fundamentalist strategist. ``Betting on Baptists is always riskier than betting on the horses.'' If moderates win, he said, ``I fear the wheels are going to come off,'' meaning the fundamentalist camp might reduce denominational support. ``They do not want to go back to funding that which to them is unconscionable,'' he said in an interview. Vestal, of the Atlanta suburb of Dunwoody, Ga., said what he characterized as the ``ruthless and destructive'' system of ``enforced conformity'' by fundamentalists cannot continue without causing widespread non-participation by moderates. However, Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, the candidate of the controlling fundamentalist wing, said the denomination had been saved from a ``drift leftward.'' He urged that ``we make complete the course correction and return'' to belief in the ``inspired, infallible, inerrant word of God.'' The belief that the Bible is without error historically, scientifically, theologically and in other areas has been the fundamentalist rallying cry in gaining denominational control. Most Southern Baptists are conservative theologically and committed to the Bible as the rule of faith, but historically have insisted on allowing individuals some leeway in interpreting it. Some moderates, including Vestal, espouse a fundamentalist, literalistic view of Scripture, but contend room should be allowed for diverse views. The church's power lies in its presidency. The president's appointive power determines trustees of the denomination's network of agencies, seminaries and other institutions. For 11 years, fundamentalists have held the top office. They have tightened requirements and questioned the beliefs of thousands of denominational staff workers, including seminary professors. The contest is viewed as the moderates' last organized election effort in the foreseeable future. There were thousands of delegates to the convention, called ``messengers,'' in town Monday, and the number was expected to surpass 30,000 before Tuesday's formal opening at the Louisiana Superdome. The Rev. Adrian Rogers of Memphis, Tenn., a fundamentalist leader and past president, told a pastors' conference Monday that he would reassess his participation in the denomination if the moderate wing wins. ``It is better to be divided by truth than to be united in error,'' Rogers said. ``Our beloved denomination is fragmented,'' Carolyn Weatherford Crumpler of Cincinnati, who is backing Vestal and who for 15 years headed the church's influential Women's Missionary Union, told a women's meeting. ``The wounded spirit of Southern Baptists needs to be lanced and opened to the healing air of God's grace,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Sharon: Force Rather Than Finesse
With AM-Israel-Politics, Bjt
LaserPhoto JRL3
DOC.TEXT: Ariel Sharon, Israel's most charismatic hawk, believes the Jewish state must rely on military might rather than the art of diplomacy to ensure its survival. The burly former defense minister and engineer of the 1982 invasion of Lebanon will become Israel's housing minister in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new government that received parliamentary approval Monday. In that post, Sharon will be in charge of coordinating the absorption of tens of thousands of Soviet immigrants expected to arrive in the Jewish state in the 1990s. Critics fear Sharon could raise tensions between Israel and the United States by channeling Soviet immigrants into the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The U.S. administration opposes moving Soviet Jews into the occupied territories, which it calls an obstacle to peace. Sharon has remained mum about his plans. ``I will only repeat that Israel is a democratic state and citizens can live where they want,'' he said Sunday. Sharon, 62, who has often followed his own path in politics, recently angered Washington with his active support of a Jewish settlement in Jerusalem's Christian quarter. Sharon would stroll over daily from his nearby apartment in the Moslem quarter as a show of Israel's sovereignty over the disputed city. He moved into the Moslem quarter in December 1987 and his apartment has a permanent detachment of soldiers and paramilitary border police standing guard outside. Sharon has set his sights on succeeding Shamir as prime minister and the two traded bitter insults a few months ago when Sharon led a campaign to torpedo Shamir's proposal for peace talks with the Palestinians. The hard-line conditions Sharon wanted to append to Shamir's peace plan have all been adopted as part of the new government's guidelines. But the Israeli-born Sharon's attempts to become prime minister have been thwarted by his responsibility for the much-criticized war in Lebanon in which hundreds of Israeli troops were killed. Sharon was forced to resign as defense minister in 1983 when an Israeli inquiry commission found him indirectly responsible for the slayings of hundreds of Palestinians by Israeli-backed Lebanese forces in the Sabra and Chatilla refugee camps in Beirut. Sharon often boasts about how he crushed Arab unrest when he served as army commander in the Gaza Strip in 1971 and says it should be used as a model for suppressing the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied lands. But critics have charged that Sharon's ruthless 1971 campaign was against guerrilla cells and that the current uprising is a popular revolt consisting mainly of stoning attacks. Last year, Sharon called on the Israeli government to ``liquidate'' PLO chief Yasser Arafat.

DOC.HEAD: Americans From War-torn Liberia Arrive in South Carolina
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
LaserPhotos CHT1,4
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of U.S. citizens returned to America on Monday after fleeing war-torn Liberia, where rebels are trying to topple the government of President Samuel K. Doe. ``It feels wonderful. It feels great'' to be back in the United States, said the Rev. Henry Hungerpiller, a 69-year-old Orangeburg native who has served as a missionary in Liberia for 35 years. The evacuees, urged by the U.S. government to leave the West African nation because of warfare, on Sunday flew from the capital of Monrovia, Liberia, to Abidjan, capital of neighboring Ivory Coast. They transferred to an American Trans Air chartered flight, and arrived at Charleston International Airport at 12:25 p.m. EDT. At least 170 of the 349 passengers were children, many of whom received stuffed animals from Salvation Army workers at the Charleston airport. Many evacuees declined to talk to reporters, apparently concerned about the effect on friends in Liberia or their chances to return. But those who did speak said fighting was intense, and many appeared thankful to be out of the country. ``Most of the people in Monrovia are very much afraid,'' Hungerpiller said. ``We didn't see any fighting, but they were getting closer and closer all the time.'' Hungerpiller worked at a Bible school of about 600 students, 12 miles outside the capital, until it was shuttered because of the fighting. Conditions in Liberia are ``terrible. There is fighting all over,'' said Solon de Joachim, an educator and businessman en route to New York with two sons and two daughters to meet his wife and five other children. Johnny Connelly, a 26-year-old missionary from Madison, Ga., said basic necessities in Liberia were in short supply before he fled with his wife, Janice, and their 2-year-old son, Josiah. ``It's very tense. Commodities are running short. Rice is disappearing and gas is disappearing,'' Connelly said. ``The United States has been warning us for weeks to go and leave and now was about our last chance before the rebels come into Monrovia,'' he said. State Department spokesman Jay Rini said there are no plans for additional flights from Liberia to Charleston. The evacuees were flown to Charleston because local authorities have experience handling similiar situations, Rini said. In 1983, American college students were evacuated to Charleston following the U.S. invasion of Grenada, and last spring military dependants from Panama were evacuated through Charleston. The Liberia evacuees were greeted at the airport by state Department of Social Services workers whose job it was to make sure they had enough money funds to travel to their final destinations in the United States. The department provides those who need financial help with federal loans, spokeswoman Norma Anderson said. In Liberia on Monday, peace talks between government and rebel negotiators aimed at ending the civil war stalled as rebel officials had difficulty getting their negotiators to the site in neighboring Sierra Leone. The 5{-month-old civil war aimed at ousting President Doe has left more than 1,000 dead.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Sentenced to 6 Months; First Iran-Contra Prison Term
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 17th graf: ``North, who,'' with North comment
DOC.TEXT: Former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter was sentenced to six months in prison Monday by a judge who accused him of usurping the power of Congress by lying about the Iran-Contra affair. The sentence imposed by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene was the first prison term for any of the seven people convicted as a result of the affair. Greene said letting Poindexter off without a prison term ``would be tantamount to a statement that a scheme to lie to and obstruct Congress is of no great moment.'' The judge delivered a stern lecture along with the sentence, saying Poindexter violated ``a principle fundamental to this constitutional republic _ that those elected by and responsible to the people shall make the important policy decisions.'' ``Their decisions may not be nullified by appointed officials who happen to be in positions that give them the ability to operate programs prohibited by law,'' the judge said. He said Poindexter showed ``no evidence of recognizing that principle and the seriousness of its violation.'' Greene allowed Poindexter to remain free while he appeals five felony convictions of conspiracy, making false statements and obstruction. And the judge did not impose a fine, noting that Poindexter had already incurred huge legal bills. However, Greene said that allowing Poindexter to get off without a prison term ``would be tantamount to a statement that to lie to and obstruct Congress was of no great moment.'' ``The Congress can't fulfill its constitutional duties if it is obstructed by high-ranking officials,'' the judge said. Poindexter, 53, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until revelations about the Iran-Contra affair forced his resignation in November 1986, is the highest-ranking Reagan administration official to be convicted of a felony. He was found guilty of lying to Congress in 1986 by falsely assuring lawmakers that his staff was not secretly helping arm the Nicaraguan Contras and by giving false testimony and preparing an inaccurate chronology to conceal U.S. involvement in a 1985 shipment of missiles to Iran. Six other men, including retired Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, a former Poindexter aide, have been placed on probation after being convicted or pleading guilty to crimes in the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter showed little emotion, except to smile at his wife Linda, after the sentence was announced. The couple kissed and walked arm-and-arm out of the courtroom after the 40-minute proceeding. As the Poindexters left the U.S. Courthouse, they briefly joined a throng of 30 supporters who were carrying banners and chanting, ``Full pardon now.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there would be no White House comment on the sentence. Asked if he could rule out a pardon by President Bush of his colleague from the Reagan administration, Fitzwater said: ``I can rule out having any comment on this matter while the case is under appeal.'' North, who was sentenced to community service in addition to probation, told CBS News, ``Admiral Poindexter is, as he has always been, a good and decent man and I think it's a crying shame that he's been treated so shabbily afrter spending more than 30 years in the service of his country.'' Greene said that Poindexter, North and others involved in the Iran-Contra affair ``carried out their own private policy'' by helping arm the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress passed legislation forbidding further U.S. military aid. ``Admiral Poindexter and his associates obstructed the Congress, nullifying the decisions that body had made on the issues of supplies to the Contras,'' Greene said. ``They decided the policy of the Boland Amendment was wrong _ they went about to violate it on a large scale and for a lengthy period, and then to lie about their activities to prevent the public from finding out,'' Greene said. Prosecutor Dan K. Webb had urged the judge to ignore any argument that lying to Congress ``is a technical violation of the law.'' ``This case is a classic example of what happens when these laws are violated,'' Webb said. ``We literally had this admiral and one very misguided and confused lieutenant colonel operating a private war in Nicaragua and Congress didn't know about it.'' Afterward, Webb said Greene had imposed ``a very fair and very proper sentence'' that would be a warning to other public officials. Defense attorney Richard W. Beckler urged Greene to spare Poindexter a prison term, saying the retired rear admiral had ``has always put his devotion to the country above any selfish interests of his own.'' While he held a high office, ``I don't think anyone can appreciate the power and pressure that bears on that,'' Beckler said. ``Every step can be a misstep,'' the defense lawyer added. ``Clearly missteps were taken here.'' Webb disputed Beckler's argument that Poindexter should be placed on probation because North and others were not given prison terms. ``John Poindexter is the superior and he, unfortunately, has to be held accountable for the events that made up Iran-Contra,'' Webb said. Under new sentencing guidelines that do not apply to the case because they took effect after the Iran-Contra affair, Poindexter could have been ordered to serve 21 months to 27 months in prison, Greene said. But the judge said it would be unfair to order such a long sentence while other Iran-Contra figures ``enjoyed the benefits of probation.'' In a clear reference to the testimony North gave at his own trial last year, the judge said that Poindexter ``unlike many defendants, did not take the stand to exculpate himself by lying under oath.'' The judge said that after the Iran-Contra affair unraveled, Poindexter and North ``engaged in the destruction of evidence _ one step ahead of the Congress and two steps ahead of the attorney general and the FBI.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rafsanjani Escaped Third Attempt on His Life
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has escaped an assassination attempt, the third reported since last fall, Iran's dissident Mujahedeen Khalq said Monday.
