DOC.HEAD: U.S. Holdings Reorganized, Further Consolidations Studied
DOC.TEXT: Nestle Holdings Inc. on Monday announced a reorganization of several of its businesses in the United States, including its coffee and ice cream operations. The coffee units of Nestle Foods Co. will be joined with Nestle-owned Hills Bros. Coffee Co. to form Nestle-Hills Coffee Co. The new company will be based in San Francisco and will include the brands Nescafe, Hills Bros., Tasters Choice, MJB, Chase and Sanborn, and Sarks and Zoegas. The ice cream and dairy businesses of Nestle and the Carnation Co. will be folded together to form Nestle Ice Cream Co., which will market all brands currently handled by the two separate units. Major manufacturing plants for the ice cream unit will be managed from Los Angeles. In a third change, the Stouffer Restaurant Co. will be merged with the Stouffer Hotel Co. to form the Stouffer Hospitality Group. The headquarters of the combined companies will continue to be in Cleveland. Further steps to consolidate businesses operated by the U.S. subsidiary of the big Swiss foods company are under study. Specifically, reorganization in the management of food services sales and product distribution is being studied, the company said in a news release. James M. Biggar, chairman of Nestle Holdings, said the changes are aimed at eliminating overlap and taking advantage of operating efficiencies. ``Nestle in the United States has been organized primarily along the lines of how it was acquired,'' he said. ``Now, it will seek to maximize efficiencies resulting from its marketing power and distribution strength to achieve greater focus.''

Australian Treasurer Paul Keating said Monday that his government would object to British publisher Robert Maxwell's plans to take a 49 percent stake in the West Australian Newspaper. Maxwell plans to buy the holding from troubled Australian financier Alan Bond's Bell Group Ltd. for the equivalent of about $192.5 million. It amounts to a controlling interest which would run counter to the country's laws on foreign press ownership, Keating said at a London news conference. Keating said the Australian government has ``always taken a very strict view of newspaper ownership'' and would not agree to the sale as it now stands. Keating defined as ``controlling'' anything above a 25 percent interest. He declined to comment further. ``I am puzzled by Mr. Keating's alleged remarks at the press conference in London today, stating that Australian law prohibits foreign ownership of newspapers with an excess of 25 percent,'' Maxwell said Monday night. ``To my knowledge no such legislation exists in Australia.'' Maxwell added that it was ``injudicious'' of Keating to comment before receiving Mirror Group Newspapers' application. Two years ago, the Australian government rejected a Maxwell bid for the Melbourne Age. Under the deal announced earlier Monday, Maxwell was planning to take a 49 percent stake in the West Australian through his Mirror Group PLC. Bell, which also holds 49 percent of the Perth Daily News and several suburban newspapers, was to retain a 50 percent share, while an identified ``distinguished Australian citizen'' was to hold the remaining 1 percent. Maxwell already holds a 14.9 percent interest in Bell, though the completion of the purchase is still pending a legal challenge by Australia's National Companies and Securities Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices ended mixed Monday, with crude oil posting modest gains and unleaded gasoline and heating oil declining. Traders described activity as lackluster in the absence of any new market-moving news. They said the market virtually ignored the continued burning of a supertanker in the Gulf Coast _ the biggest oil news of the day _ since shipping into Southern ports isn't expected to be affected. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 4 cents to settle at $16.82 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract gained 11 cents Friday. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery lost 0.71 cent to close at 55.88 cents a gallon, after falling 1.02 cents Friday. The July contract for wholesale home heating oil, which rose 0.31 cent Friday, settled at 46.72 cents a gallon, off 0.49 cent. In natural gas trading, prices ended mixed. The July contract closed marginally lower at $1.572 per 1,000 cubic feet compared with $1.575 Friday. Later contracts settled slightly lower to slightly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: A lack of fresh economic news led to a slow day for currency traders Monday as the dollar was lower against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold prices were mixed. ``It's been very quiet today, all day long,'' said Lorenzo Troni, vice president for foreign exchange at PaineWebber International Ltd. in New York. ``I think everyone is waiting for some economic data.'' Later this week, the government is to release reports on retail sales, producer prices and consumer prices. The market apparently is anticipating lower inflation and lower retail sales that could prompt the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates, leading to a weaker dollar, Troni said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.45 yen to a closing 154.10 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 154.45 yen. In New York, it climbed to 154.77 yen from 153.49 late Friday. One trader, Linda McLaughlin of Chemical Bank, attributed the dollar's strength against the yen to money from individual investors in Japan who have just received semi-annual bonuses. The workers are apparently looking to invest in U.S. markets, she said. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6858, stronger than $1.6843 late Friday. The pound traded at $1.6860 late Monday in New York, more expensive than $1.6840 late Friday. Other New York rates late Monday, compared with Friday's late rates, included: 1.6927 West German marks, down from 1.6975; 1.4430 Swiss francs, down from 1.4495; 5.6965 French francs, down from 5.7145; 1.1710 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1743; and 1,243.25 Italian lire, down from 1,248.00. Other dollar rates in Europe compared with late Friday's levels included: 1.4400 Swiss francs, down from 1.4480; 5.6900 French francs, down from 5.7155; 1.9040 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9088; 1,242.75 Italian lire, down from 1,248.50; 1.6910 West German marks, down from 1.6973 marks; and 1.1705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1743. Gold bullion for current delivery rose 70 cents to $356.40 a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $355.10 a troy ounce, up 10 cents from late Friday. Gold was quoted at a bid of $354.45 per troy ounce in London late Monday, down from $354.50 a troy ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $355, up from $354 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.28 to close at a bid of $355.75 an ounce. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, down from Friday's $5.02. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery rose 0.5 cent to close at $5.012 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Couple Settle Insider Trading Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese businessman and his bond trader-wife settled federal allegations Monday that they traded in the stock of John O. Butler Co. using illegal insider information about a pending buyout. Jiro Yamazaki and his wife, Ikuko Sekiguchi-Yamazaki, agreed to pay $99,703 in fines, restitution and interest without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced. The couple's attorney was not in his office when called for comment Monday afternoon. The couple, both Japanese nationals who live in the New York City suburb of Scarsdale, were accused of making $45,000 in illegal trading profits. They allegedly traded using confidential corporate information that Butler, a Chicago-based oral hygiene products maker, was going to be acquired by Sunstar Corporation, a Japanese health and beauty aids maker. They were accused of buying Butler Co. stock for between $13.25 and $13.75 a share before a $25 per share tender offer was made public in March 1988. According to the SEC, Yamazaki was assistant treasurer in the New York office of a major international bank that was part of a consortium financing Sunstar's tender offer for Butler. Ms. Sekiguchi-Yamazaki, who allegedly purchased the stock with information supplied by her husband, was identified as a bond salesperson for a securities firm in New York. The SEC declined to identify the employer of either Yamazaki or his wife.

DOC.HEAD: GM Offers Rebate on Minivan
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Monday announced a $1,000 rebate on its Oldsmobile Silhouette minivan. The new program, along with current rebates of $2,500 on the Oldsmobile Toronado and $1,000 on the Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera, will expire Aug. 2. Consumers may choose financing with interest rates as low as 7.9 percent, depending on the loan term, in lieu of the rebates.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Takeover Rumors, Foxboro Exploring Possible `Alliance'
DOC.TEXT: Foxboro Co., a leading maker of systems that control manufacturing processes, said Monday it is exploring what it called an ``alliance'' with other firms that could involve the sale of the company. The announcement came amid speculation that began last week about a possible takeover of the company. The talk drove up the price of Foxboro stock, which closed Monsday at $30 a share, up $1.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. A week ago the stock sold for $24 a share. Last year it traded as low as $18.62{, said Albert Turner, a securities analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Foxboro systems are used to record and control processes in manufacturing such as temperature, pressure, humidity and liquid levels. Its customers are largely in the chemical and petroleum industries and include such familiar names as Exxon Corp. and Dow Chemical Co. The international company, based in the suburb of Foxboro, employs 7,000 people. The company reported a net loss for 1989 of $4.6 million, or 37 cents a share, on sales of $598 million. In a carefully worded announcement, the company said it was ``exploring alternatives with respect to a possible strategic alliance with a limited number of firms.'' Such an alliance, it said, ``could add complementary strengths to the company's existing strong process control capability.'' The deal it is exploring, the company added, ``could involve an equity investment in all or a substantial portion of its stock.'' It also said, however, that no decision had been made on whether such a deal might even transpire. Telephone calls to John C. Fuller, a member of the Foxboro board and a vice president for investor relations, were not returned. Foxboro would be an attractive buy, Turner said. Among its attributes are an old and loyal customer base and a new product line first offered two years ago that enables Foxboro systems to be integrated with those of other companies. But the new system has had costly bugs in it, Turner said. ``It's not clear that all of the problems have been completely worked out in this new system, and this company has had to borrow money to finance its operations in the last four years,'' Turner said. ``They could use a little financial backing.'' Robert Sullivan, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc. in New York, said Foxboro is coming out of a restructuring period. ``The company's record in the last few years has been quite erratic, which has led to some dissatisfaction on the part of some stockholders,'' Sullivan said. ``It's a big and growing market and as (manufacturing) companies are forced by law to reduce pollution, one of the things they will be forced to spend money on is equipment to reduce pollution,'' Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont To End Orlon Production
DOC.TEXT: Forty years after it introduced Orlon to the world of sweaters, socks and knit outerwear, Du Pont Co. announced Monday it will stop production of the acrylic fiber as soon as possible. The fiber has been overproduced worldwide and consumers now prefer cotton and polyester fabrics, said Paul G. Gillease, director of Du Pont's textile division. ``As a result, the business has not been sufficiently profitable in recent years,'' Gillease said. Byron J. McCutchen, the company's Orlon business manager, said that for the past several years, Orlon sales have been about $200 million annually. Du Pont plans to focus production on its Lycra spandex fiber, used in clothing such as swimming suits and leotards; nylon; and its Dacron polyester. Gillease said those fibers ``present significant growth opportunities (and) will be more beneficial to the long-term interests of Du Pont and its customers and will strengthen our position in the U.S. apparel market.'' Orlon is produced at Du Pont plants in Camden, S.C., and Waynesboro, Va. There are about 725 employees divided between the two plants. J.J. Pryor, a company spokeswoman, said Du Pont will try to absorb the workers into other operations. She said about 50 Orlon marketing and business employees are spread among company headquarters in Wilmington, New York and Charlotte, N.C. McCutchen said the phase-out will not affect the Beaumont, Texas, plant where acrylonitrile is produced. Acrylonitrile is the raw material used to make Orlon. McCutchen said the raw material will be sold to other companies.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Markets Rebound From Early Stumble
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures posted strong gains Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a lower opening. Analysts attributed the rebound largely to technically inspired buying. Wheat futures also advanced while oats finished lower. On other commodity markets, energy futures were mixed; pork bellies surged, leading livestock and meat futures higher; cocoa futures plummeted; and precious metals rose. Corn futures settled 3 cents to 5\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $2.89} a bushel; soybeans were 6 cents to 10{ cents higher with July at $6.08\ a bushel; wheat futures settled 1\ cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $3.32} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower across the board with July at $1.47\ a bushel. Analysts said many of the large speculators who sold soybean contracts Friday returned Monday as buyers, helping to lift soybean prices to their highest levels in two weeks. The corn market extended a strong upward trend supported by last month's rain, which delayed planting, and by perceptions that corn supplies are unusually tight. An Agriculture Department report due out Tuesday probably will confirm private expectations for ``one of the tightest relationships between corn ending stocks and demand in history,'' said William Biedermann, director of research for the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Buying enthusiasm was limited by ideas that dry weather in the Midwest will allow planting of corn and soybeans to advance, although showers are expected to return to the region later this week. In its weekly export inspections report released after the close, the USDA indicated an amount of soybeans inspected for shipment last week that was greater than the trade had expected. Energy futures prices ended mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange with crude oil posting modest gains and unleaded gasoline and heating oil declining. Traders described activity as lackluster in the absence of any new market-moving news. They said the market virtually ignored the continued burning of a supertanker in the Gulf Coast _ the biggest oil news of the day _ since shipping into Southern ports isn't expected to be affected. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 17 cents lower to 4 cents higher with July at $16.82 a barrel; heating oil was .62 cent lower to .05 cent higher with July at 46.72 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to .89 cent lower with July at 55.88 cents a gallon. Frozen pork bellies for July and August delivery rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting higher prices in the fresh-belly market and bullish chart signals. The strength in the belly market carried over to the livestock pits, helping cattle and hog futures to close higher. Live cattle settled .08 cent to .52 cent higher with June at 76.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .30 cent higher with August at 85.45 cents a pound; hogs were .25 cent to 1.08 cents higher with June at 64.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .08 cent lower to 2 cents higher with July at 69.75 cents a pound. Cocoa futures plunged in a technically inspired sell-off on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange. The market has become vulnerable to a sharp decline since fears of supply disruptions from the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, have faded. Cocoa settled $45 to $61 lower with July at $1,181 per ton. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures finished 50 cents to 70 cents higher with June at $356.40 a troy ounce; silver was 0.1 cent to 0.5 cent higher with June at $5.012 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Asbestos Fund Exploring Ways To Ease Shortfall
DOC.TEXT: The trust created in Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases said Monday it is exploring alternatives to ease a cash shortage that could delay some payments until the 21st century. John C. Sawhill, chairman of the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, issued a statement that the trust wants ``to quickly resolve the current legal issues and return (its) attention to settling claims.'' The statement did not specify alternatives being examined by the trust. The trust said it has in the past rejected money-raising methods including insurance-type deferred settlements, investment and asset management options, sale of part of its Manville stock and borrowing money. On Friday, a federal bankruptcy judge appointed New York attorney Leon Silverman, one of the architects of Manville's reoganization plan, to find ways of restructuring the $2.5 billion trust. Earlier this month, a federal judge and a New York state judge ordered the bankruptcy court to overhaul the trust. One change would be in a widely criticized payment method that compensates most claimants on the basis of when their lawsuit is filed. The trust was criticized because of a cash shortage induced by more cases, larger payouts and quicker settlements than expected. It has said some claimants filing this year will not get paid until the year 2025. The trust was formed as a separate legal entity in Manville's 1988 reorganization, six years after the Denver company was driven into bankruptcy court by lawsuits over production of asbestos. Its main asset is ownership of a majority of Manville stock. ``The parties are talking about what can be done in this situation,'' said Theodore Kleinman, the trust's chief financial officer. ``Every possible alternative will be visited in the course of that exploration. We're very anxious to try to do what's right here.'' Manville was the nation's largest maker of asbestos, the insulation and building material found to cause severe and sometimes fatal illnesses. Manville to date has settled more than 22,000 claims by victims but still has more than 130,000 pending. In the statement, the trust said it has received $958 million from Manville and its insurers to date. It said it has paid out $739 million, $638 million of that directly to claimants. Of some $219 million in cash on hand as of March 30, $113 million already is committed to paying claims over the next year. The rest of the money is designated for prior settlement claims, legal expenses and operations costs. The trust has said it will have no new income until Manville makes its first annual $75 million payment to the trust next year.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Air Signs Contract for 23 Boeing 747-400s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE incorrect reference to Korean Air ordering 33 jets. Also changes acronym ``KAL'' to Korean Air to reflect company's new style of name in grafs 2, 8 and 9. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Korean Air signed a $4.8 billion order Monday for 23 Boeing 747-400s, the third-largest order ever received by Boeing Co. in terms of contract value. The contract includes spare parts and training and commits Korean Air to more of Boeing's most sophisticated and highest-capacity jetliners than any other carrier except Japan Air Lines. JAL has signed up for 40 of the world's largest passenger jets. The Korean order is the third multibillion-dollar purchase of Boeing aircraft in as many weeks. The others also were from Asian air carriers: a $2 billion order from the Chinese government and a $3.1 billion order from Japan Air Lines. Boeing has received single orders for more planes, but only two exceed the Korean Air order in dollar value: an April 1989 order by Irish aircraft leasing company GPA Ltd. worth $9.4 billion for 182 planes, and a $7.11 billion deal for 180 planes placed a week later by United Airlines. Frank Shrontz, Boeing chairman and chief executive officer, told a news conference that the order reflects the fact that traffic growth in the Pacific has been higher than in either the United States or Europe. He also said the 747-400s, which will be equipped to carry 392 passengers each, are best suited to meet the region's long-range flights and high-capacity needs. Korean Air recently added long-range routes between Seoul and Moscow, Sydney, Toronto and Vancouver. Korean Air Senior Executive Vice President C.H. Cho said the airline also has contracts for eight other 747-400s by 1994. It already has three in service. Cho said negotiations were under way to determine which engines the new planes would use. He said Korea produces some parts for the 747, but the purchase is not dependent upon continued use of Korean-made items. Korean Ambassador Park Tong Jin said the purchase represented a ``sincere effort to reduce'' the country's trade surplus with the United States. Boeing officials said 307 of the Seattle company's 747-400s have been ordered, with 71 so far delivered to airlines around the world. The 747-400 can fly more than 8,000 miles nonstop. The planes normally sell for $116 million to $136 million each, but officials said the Korean Air price reflects the estimated value of the dollar at the time of delivery.

DOC.HEAD: Mulheren Prosecution Rests Its Case
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case Monday in the federal securities fraud trial of John A. Mulheren Jr., a former associate of convicted stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky. The defense then began its presentation in U.S. District Court by calling three prominent businessmen as character witnesses. Mulheren, 40, of Rumson, N.J., is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations involving his friendship with Boesky. He is accused of scheming with Boesky to manipulate the price of Gulf & Western Inc. stock and concealing ownership of other stocks to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. The first defense witness was Alan C. Greenberg, the chairman and chief executive officer of Bear Stearns & Co., who said Mulheren was a friend and business associate. ``I would trust everything I have to John Mulheren,'' Greenberg said during questioning by Mulheren's attorney, Thomas Puccio. The other defense witnesses were Samuel Belzberg, chairman of First City Financial Corp. in Canada, and Jack Nash, the former chairman of Oppenheimer & Co. _ both of whom described Mulheren as honest and honorable. The high point of the government's case was the three-day appearance last month of Boesky, who was the main witness against Mulheren. Boesky paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle the biggest insider trading case ever. In exchange, he gave government investigators incriminating information about a number of his associates. Mulheren's trial began with jury selection May 14. The government presented testimony from about 18 witnesses over three weeks. Other prosecution witnesses included Boesky's former head trader, Michael Davidoff, and Mark Davis, the chairman of Paramount Communications Inc. The prosecution on Monday also rested its case against Mulheren's co-defendant, Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's firm, Jamie Securities. He is charged with conspiracy and record-keeping violations.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's No. 2 Bank Has Rating Lowered Over Real Estate Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Concern about Chase Manhattan Corp.'s exposure to the nation's shaky real estate market triggered a downgrading of the credit rating of the nation's second-largest bank Monday. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it was lowering it ``any incremental effect'' on Chase's costs because the bank has little need to borrow long-term funds, Rautenberg said. Thomas H. Hanley, a banking analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., agreed. Although the bank's long-term debt was downgraded, its commercial paper rating was left unchanged, he noted. Banks are major issuers of commercial paper to obtain short-term funds. The nation's banks are likely to be plagued by a weak real estate market for some time to come, Hanley said. ``I don't see any quick turnaround,'' he said. Moody's lowered its rating on senior debt of Chase Manhattan Corp., the holding company, to Baa2 from Baa1. The rating on long-term deposits of Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., the main banking subsidiary, was lowered to A3 from A2. Ratings on other long-term debt of the holding company and its subsidiaries was dropped one notch. Tanya Azarchs, a vice president at S&P, said her agency hasn't changed its ratings on Chase but was reviewing major banks largely because of the sluggish real estate market. ``It's a situation that does disturb us,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Plans to Implement Union-Rejected Contract
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also nmoved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: NBC said Monday it will implement a proposed four-year contract rejected last month by members of the network's major union. The network said the contract would go into effect June 20. Although no new negotiations were scheduled, ``we're optimistic that something will be worked (out) before that June 20 date,'' said John Krieger, a spokesman for the union, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians. The union, which says it has 2,373 members at NBC and NBC-owned operations, struck NBC in 1987 in a bitter walkout that lasted 17 weeks. No walkout is imminent in the current dispute. Union members have not taken a strike authorization vote and are continuing to work, Krieger said. ``We're hopeful we can bring a resolution to this before (contract) implementation,'' he said. The union's members, in balloting conducted in April and May, overwhelmingly rejected NBC's March 30 contract offer; 1,601 to 354. The main issues are job security and jurisdiction, Krieger said. The majority of NABET's 1,300 members are engineers and technicians. The union also represents newswriters, couriers, building maintenance employees and operations directors. NBC says its offer establishes parity with union contracts in force at CBS and ABC. NBC has told NABET it would consider a small number of modest changes in its offer if that would lead to speedy union ratification, network spokesman Joe Rutledge said Monday. However, he said the union, in its last meeting with management May 16, ``told us they consider further talks to be futile.'' Rutledge and Krieger said the contract talks did not cover a new 24-hour news service to NBC affiliate stations that NBC plans to start in January.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Ends Contract Ban on Hughes Missile Unit
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has lifted its suspension of business with Hughes Aircraft Co.'s missile unit, which resulted from the company's dealing in secret Pentagon documents, Hughes said Monday. The division was barred May 9 from bidding on programs and receiving new government contracts in a case stemming from Hughes' guilty pleas to two federal counts last March. Hughes admitted its executives trafficked in secret Pentagon documents to gain a competitive edge. It was fined $3.6 million. At the time of the suspension, the government had threatened to bar the missile division from bidding on new work for up to three years. Prosecutors said the documents were obtained by a marketing executive at Hughes' missile group. Hughes said that, in settling the case, it had agreed to tighten security, change procedures for marketing operations and conduct a marketing training program. It also agreed to continue a companywide ethics program established several years ago. The criminal plea entered by Hughes was part of the large ``Operation Undercover'' criminal probe, in which GTE, Boeing and RCA also entered guilty pleas.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Boeing led ...' to CORRECT order to $4.8 billion sted $48 billion
DOC.TEXT: The stock market snapped out of last week's slump Monday with a rally led by blue chips. But trading set its slowest pace in more than two months. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 38.59 points last week, rebounded 30.19 to 2,892.57. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 918 up, 563 down and 516 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 119.55 million shares, down from 142.60 million in the previous session and the lightest total since a 114.97 million-share day on April 9. Analysts said traders were doing some selective ``bargain-hunting'' in the blue chips while they awaited a broad array of economic reports due from the government this week. Among the monthly statistics on the agenda for Wall Street are the producer price index of finished goods, due on Thursday, and the consumer price index and the nation's trade balance, both on Friday. If all goes as expected, brokers say, the data will support the popular view that economic growth is plodding along at a pace slow enough to permit inflation and interest rates to ease. However, they add, any surprises in the numbers could unsettle some of the optimism generated during the rally that carried stock prices to new highs as recently as last Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 145.41 million shares. Boeing led the active list, up 3 at 58{ on turnover of more than 2.3 million shares. The stock, which was split 3-for-2 effective with Monday's trading, reponded to word of a $4.8 billion order from Korean Airlines for Boeing 747-400 jets. Energy stocks attracted buyers after dropping last week in line with falling oil prices. Exxon gained ~ to 47~; Chevron 1[ to 70|; Atlantic Richfield 2 to 116~; Amoco ~ to 51{, and Texaco ] to 57~. Elsewhere among the blue chips, International Business Machines rose 1[ to 119~; Coca-Cola { to 44{; General Motors | to 49[; American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 42\, and DuPont { to 39|. Microcom Inc. tumbled 8{ to 9} as the most active issue in the over-the-counter market. Late Friday the company projected a loss for the fiscal quarter ending June 30, saying major domestic distributors were overstocked with its software and modem products. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $22.14 billion, or 0.64 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.37 to 197.42. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.79 to 421.22, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.92 at 361.63. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.92 to 462.79. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 362.32, up 1.15.

DOC.HEAD: One in Six New Jobs Projected to be in California
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf: ``Total U.S.,'' to state that inflation adjustment is in terms of dollars of 1982 buying power. FYI, the adjustment in the three sidebar tables is also made to 1982 dollars. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-State Income-List, BC-State Jobs-List, BC-State Population-List
DOC.TEXT: One of every six jobs created through the turn of the century is expected to be in California, reflecting the continued shift of economic activity to the Sun Belt, the government said Monday. ``California is projected to gain 3.4 million of the 18.9 million new jobs created nationally'' from 1988 to 2000, said the forecast by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. That would give the state 19 million jobs. ``Florida and Texas are projected to have increases of more than 1 million jobs each,'' to 8 million and 9.7 million respectively, the department said. National employment opportunities are expected to rise 14.3 percent to 151.5 million jobs. The study projected that the fastest job growth will be in Nevada, up 31.5 percent to 847,000, and Arizona, up 26.7 percent to 2.3 million. Those two states also should show the fastest growth rates in total personal income and population, the department said. ``The projected growth in Nevada and Arizona reflects rapid population growth and strength in their economies, in part due to the continued shift in economic activity toward the Sun Belt,'' the study said. ``Florida, Utah, California and Hawaii also are projected to show rapid growth.'' California will continue to be the nation's most populous state, growing 17.1 percent to 33.2 million people. It also will be first in total personal income, up 33 percent to $568 billion. Personal income will jump 46.2 percent to $21.7 billion in Nevada and 40.6 percent to $59 billion in Arizona. Total U.S. personal income is expected to advance 26.2 percent to $4.11 trillion. The income projections are adjusted for inflation and stated in terms of dollars of 1982 buying power. Connecticut is projected to continue having the highest average per capita income, rising 10.8 percent to $20,503. Mississippi, although gaining 19.0 percent, is expected to still be last, with $10,631. The national average will be an estimated $15,345, an increase of 15.9 percent. The population in Nevada is projected to rise the fastest, 29.8 percent, to 1.4 million. If the projection proves to be true, Arizona will be next, with its population rising 21.4 percent to 4.2 million. Florida would be third, up 18.2 percent to 14.6 million. The national growth rate is expected to be 8.9 percent, with the nation having 268 million in the year 2000. Populations are projected to increase in every state except Wyoming, Louisiana and West Virginia, expected to post declines of 1.0 percent, 0.1 percent and 0.4 percent respectively.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Gain Slightly, Dollar Eases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange recovered from an early setback to stand marginally higher at the end of Tuesday's morning session, and the dollar retreated against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which fell almost 260 points in early trading, recovered to stand 2.07 points higher at 32,542.25. The index dropped 453.11 points on Monday. The dollar was changing hands at 153.84 yen at late morning, down from an opening of 154.38 yen and off from Monday's close of 154.10 yen. It ranged between 153.80 yen and 154.45 yen during morning trading. Yoshio Ogawa, chief dealer of Nikko Securities Co., attributed the Nikkei's early decline to arbitrage selling, in which investors attempt to take profits between the spot and futures markets. ``After a round of sellings, though, traders started buying underpriced issues,'' Ogawa said. The yen's early weakness against the dollar also prompted some selling, he added, but strength in the bond market provided support. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.59 points from Monday's close of 87.18. The gain pushed the yield down to 7.055 percent from 7.14 percent. Ogawa said many traders remained cautious ahead of the release of the Bank of Japan's Tankan, or short-term economic forecast, scheduled for Tuesday afternoon. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's decline to technical adjustments. Most participants didn't want to trade actively ahead of a series of releases of key U.S. economic indicators this week, they said. Figures for U.S. retail sales, producer and consumer prices in May and trade figures for April are due to be released this week in Washington.
